Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, the city at the center of a measles epidemic with 942 cases. It is not yet known if measles was the main cause of death. He had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash after being discharged. He saw a GP with a rash from head to foot but not on his arms. He was found dead the next morning. Laboratory tests confirmed a diagnosis of measles, but further tests are needed to determine the cause of death.

Vincent Hudson, 54, has been charged with a historical offense on a boy under 16. The attack was reported to have taken place in 2001. Mr. Hudson is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Neil Aspin's team is unbeaten in nine National League matches, while Adam Lockwood's side is unbeaten in five. Guiseley went ahead with a goal by Jake Lawlor. Gateshead leveled the score with a goal by Wes York. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands to increase capacity, an alternative to building a new stadium. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed work would begin after a shareholder meeting on Tuesday. The work was approved by Bristol City Council in November. If there is no judicial review by March, redevelopment plans will begin in May.

Cuadrilla suspended drilling after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) will examine the data before deciding whether to resume. The BGS said a tremor on 1 April shared a "similar location and mechanism". Shale gas drilling, known as "fracking", involves shattering rocks underground to release gas. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution. There have been two small earthquakes in Lancashire since fracking began in March. The BGS said that injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause earthquakes. The latest quake was felt by at least one person and occurred at a depth of approximately 2km.

Angus Carpenter, 62, of Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015. He was cleared of two other counts. Sgt Chris Gaynor said Carpenter gave the impression he was collecting cash for the Hillsborough Justice Campaign. Carpenter said he had piped for the charity in the past but on this occasion he was simply busking. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, said he had given Carpenter permission to display a banner but not to collect funds. Carpenter said the banner was a tribute to the victims. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich defeated QPR 3-0 with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence. QPR's Alex Smithies miscued a clearance leading to one of the goals. Ipswich had other scoring opportunities, while QPR had few chances, with a late header hitting the post. The win moved Ipswich to 14th place, while QPR dropped to 15th.

Wells, 23, scored 373 runs at 28.69 with a strike rate of 138.66 in the T20 Blast last season. Wells said the club is going in the right direction and the environment created by the coaches is of elite performance.

The Reds, who are fifth in National Two South, beat third-placed Chinnor 29-12 for a second win in a row. Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams led the team. The Reds face seven teams who are below them in the table in their next eight games, as well as league leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher believes his side still has a lot of room for improvement.

Nazrul, also called Nazu, a 28-year-old Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun. The incident caused outrage and protests in India. Nazrul was identified from CCTV footage and was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata. Five other suspects have named Nazrul as the person who raped the nun. Police have identified eight suspects in the attack, with two still untraced. Milon Sarkar was previously arrested and described as the leader of the gang. The attack occurred on March 14 in Ranaghat, where money was stolen, the building ransacked, and the nun was raped.

This interactive video features Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, discussing why we change what we buy. The arrival of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports all affected items on sale and popular among UK consumers. The video also explores how ownership and ranking of some of the biggest brands in the UK is changing.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked by someone claiming to work for BT on September 15th. A woman in Stranraer lost money to a caller claiming to be from BT technical support seven days later. The caller gained remote access to her computer to take the cash. Police are asking people to be careful when answering cold calls from people trying to gain remote access to their computer and to never give out banking details over the phone.

Duffy, 37, has joined Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. The Scotland assistant coach will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse. Duffy has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter were sent to Sker Beach at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. A rider with head injuries was found unconscious on wet sand and was treated before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system to improve on the current ground-based radar system. This decision was made following the disappearance of MH370 in March 2014. The new system will enable satellites to receive transmissions, allowing real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world. The current system leaves around 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The UN's aviation arm has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines.

Julian Hernandez disappeared at age five and is now 18, living with his father in Cleveland. His father, Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is being held at a jail in Ohio. The FBI received a tip on 30 October that this teenager may be the long-missing child. His father is also charged with tampering with records in Ohio. Authorities suspected around the time of the boy's disappearance that his father was possibly the culprit.

A fire at a site on Duncan Street on March 2nd caused travel delays and reduced train services. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The fire service raised concerns to the EA in February over the impact a fire could have. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, effective August 7th, and the company is required to remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia put forward bills linked to the situation in Ukraine. Separatist and pro-Russian feelings are strong in Ukraine's Crimea region. Russian MPs say a referendum or a plea from a territory's leaders would be enough to trigger the new provisions. One bill would speed up the procedures for issuing Russian passports, and applicants would not have to pay a state tax, have previous residence in Russia, have sufficient funds, or give up their Ukrainian citizenship. The bill is aimed at supporting the fraternal people of Ukraine, especially the Russian-speaking ones.

McLaren, a team with a history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling. Their slump began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and now the problem lies with the Honda power-unit. Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, the team is aiming for a fourth or third row grid position. McLaren has had periods of success, including a dominant era with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and later with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines. They were involved in scandals in 2007 and 2009. Ron Dennis, who has been involved with the team for a long time, believes they will return to success and break Mercedes' dominance.

Tommy Baker, 44, from Everton, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27 and died in hospital. Three Liverpool men, two aged 29 and one aged 32, were arrested and are in police custody. Police are searching for a silver VW polo that left the scene and are asking people captured on CCTV near the market to come forward.

This article discusses five ways to enjoy Christmas online. Everyday Church Online runs virtual services, the game Guardians of Ancora allows players to rediscover Bible stories, Viral.de created a video called The Digital Story of Nativity, the Churches Advertising Network created a video called Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle, and Next Manga launched its Manga Messiah book in app and e-book form. Many groups are also using social media to connect with their communities.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land. Backers have offered around 320 hectares replacement land. The inquiry has heard conflicting accounts from experts over claims the circuit would damage habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales said it was "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land was of equal value, but it was not opposing the development overall. An ecology report presented by the developers said there would be a "net gain" in biodiversity. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, before Welsh government ministers have the final say.

Chechen Muslim clerics said a report about the detention of over 100 people suspected of being homosexual insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, and called for retribution. Novaya Gazeta, who published the report, said this was a call for reprisals against journalists. The LGBT Network said the report was true and that detainees were tortured. Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, and his spokesman said there were no gay people in Chechnya. The Chechens' spiritual leader confirmed that "retribution" was part of the resolution. Novaya Gazeta said the detainees included some influential Muslim clerics and two TV presenters. The LGBT Network is helping people flee the persecution and accuses the Russian authorities of ignoring the abuses.

Investing Solutions receives housing benefit payments by finding properties for single homeless men, referred by Fresh Start Housing. The letting agent makes money by charging housing benefit for each person in a property, rather than the property itself, resulting in a higher payout than the rent fee. Both companies are based in the same building and were set up by Samir Patel. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK. One tenant described the properties as unsuitable, with issues such as lack of heating and rats. Wandsworth Council has paid the agency more than £2.1m in the past two years.

Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13. Coach Joe Prunty's team led for most of the first three quarters before being overtaken in the last 10 minutes. GB begins their Eurobasket qualifying campaign in Hungary. Prunty said the key to the qualifiers will be completing on every play. The Netherlands were led by 18 points from Worthy De Jong. The Netherlands won despite the hosts' comeback in the last six minutes. Prunty was pleased with the contribution of Gordon.

The former five-weight world champion submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for a fight at 154 lbs, which requires 10oz gloves. The NAC will debate the use of 8oz gloves, which offer less cushioning but more punishing punches, on 16 August. McGregor, who has used 4oz gloves in UFC, will make his boxing debut against Mayweather, who has not knocked anyone out in 10 years. The NAC approved the fight after studying information on McGregor, including his fights with Nate Diaz. McGregor's camp hired boxing referee Joe Cortez after being advised to do so.

Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith of the Sunday Post are the last journalists working on Fleet Street, which is closing its London office. Fleet Street was once the center of British journalism, housing many national and provincial newspapers. The first British daily newspaper was published there in 1702. At its peak, it was a pinnacle for journalists, with many bars and pubs frequented by them. Over time, newspapers moved away from Fleet Street, adopting new technology. The buildings have since been repurposed.

The author stated that the comments she received reminded her how big the world is and how many more decent people there are than not. She also stated that her personal line had been crossed by some abusive comments and that she believes in standing up to bullies. She faced criticism on Twitter after donating £1m to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum and in 2008, she donated the same amount to the Labour party. She revealed she had been called "a traitor" for her political views and had blocked some abusive Twitter users she believed had been supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). She also revealed she had "responded to other really nice SNP supporters" and had discussed "how much I had in common politically with many of them". The SNP took 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland in Thursday's election and is now the third largest party in the UK.

A study by University of Edinburgh researchers found that children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action than better-off children who commit the same crime. Poverty increased the likelihood of violence and a history of being in trouble with the police was the strongest predictor of whether a young person was not in education, employment or training by the age of 18. Poorer young people were also about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts. The study also found that crime tends to be highly concentrated amongst poor people and within poor neighborhoods. The Scottish government stated that Scotland is becoming a safer place to live.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and remanded in custody. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge. Mr. Walsh was allegedly one of three people who entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr. Haugh. A fight ensued where weapons were used, and Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back. He was pronounced dead at 06:00 local time. Police recovered a knife handle and a blade at the scene.

In May 2014, Phil Flanagan tweeted that Tom Elliott harassed and shot people as a member of the UDR. Mr. Elliott served in the UDR for 10 years, between 1982 and 1992. The tweet was deleted within an hour. Mr. Flanagan has admitted that his tweet was untrue and without foundation. The insurance firm which indemnifies MLAs at Stormont has refused to cover Mr. Flanagan in respect of any compensation and costs in this case.

Hawick Knitwear, which employs more than 230 staff, has increased its production of sweaters to meet demand. The company was bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year. The firm has seen growth in its new range and its longer-established business of supplying customers who sell the garments under their private labels. Hawick Knitwear sells into Europe, the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The knitwear firm has increased its production to 9,500 sweaters each week.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School after being struck by Brian Wright, 55, who said he was blinded by the setting sun. Mr. Wright denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care. Mr. Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light and hit Mrs. Blackburn while she was on duty as a lollipop lady.

This passage describes a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise called "Dynamic Mongoose," prompted by increased Russian submarine activity. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg, searching for a German U-boat, U33. The exercise highlights the difficulty of locating submarines and the growing concern about Russia's advanced submarine fleet. It also reveals a gap in Britain's defenses due to the lack of maritime patrol aircraft. The exercise uses various technologies, including sonar, sensors, underwater drones, and maritime patrol aircraft.

United Nations officials say that genocide and ethnic cleansing could occur in South Sudan. Since violence flared in July, 340,000 people have fled to Uganda, more than any other country this year. Every day, 2,500 South Sudanese become refugees due to killing, rape, and the targeting of civilians along ethnic lines. The violence is between the Dinka and Nuer tribes, and Equatorians are also being targeted. Uganda is struggling to cope with the influx of refugees, with Bidi Bidi becoming one of the biggest refugee settlements in the world.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship on 12 November. He became a professional boxer in 2013 after quitting football. He has a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former world champion Duke McKenzie.

The new Bridgwater Community Hospital is part of a £330m investment for new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit and X-ray and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital was built in 1813 and is cramped and outdated. The total cost of the project is £33m. The aim is to get the hospital finished by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and died at Northern General hospital. The man was either in or close to a black Mercedes car when he was shot. Local residents said the man was a member of a family who live close to the scene and that relatives had been gathering for a family celebration when the attack occurred. There have been a number of shootings in Sheffield in recent weeks, including a 25-year-old man seriously injured in Shiregreen, shots fired through a living room window in Southey Green, and shots fired at houses in High Green.

Three main groups of virtual warriors are the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, use DDoS attacks and target rebel websites and accounts. Cyber Berkut is an anti-Western group that has hacked Ukrainian government websites and electronic billboards. Anonymous International publishes leaked documents from the Kremlin.

Tricia Marwick was emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to parliament. Ms. Marwick, Mr. Salmond, and Mr. McNeil are among those standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on May 5th. Mr. Salmond believes Scotland is diverse, not divided, and that the parliament should assume greater responsibility for the governance of Scotland. Mr. McNeil warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also leaving Holyrood.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is reviewing the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will be gathering evidence from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will look at factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment. The chair of Care Forum Wales is disappointed that the commissioner has not included a provider expert on the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group's pre-tax profit increased by £800,000 to £3.5m, despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m. International sales grew, and the company manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors. They also have 19 shops across Scotland under the Country Store brand. The company acknowledges the difficulty in predicting the outlook for agriculture and the impact of Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden. A man in his 80s was taken to the hospital. Detectives want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, and have warned people not to approach him. The death is being treated as murder. Ian McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, said the IMF's latest reading of the global economy shows a weakening baseline and that they are at a delicate juncture. This comes after weaker-than-expected trade figures from China. The IMF has said it is likely it will downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth when it next releases its economic predictions in April.

The council decided the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July due to problems with the new ferry. The council ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has broken down, run aground, and been suspended due to training issues. Cars have been damaged getting on and off. Local businesses have suffered losses. Compensation for businesses is up for discussion. The council authorized ramp extensions to resolve the problem of vehicles scraping the concrete. Groundings were an issue with seamanship, which has been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at about 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening.

Matching Models in London, an international temp agency, advertised for a personal assistant with a specific look, which the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called unlawful and demeaning. The agency also advertised for a "sexy female driver". The agency's founder said looks are important to their clients. The EHRC stated that first impressions are not about hair color and that the agency should act like a 21st-century business. The agency's clients include MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renualt Formula 1 team and Harrods.

The shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, was an office assistant at the school. Mahesh shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head and also shot another student, Sirisha, who suffered severe injuries. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April.

Glaad analyzed shows between June 2016 and May 2017 and counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters has risen from seven to 16. More than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television. Glaad's study based its findings on scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to not stand for re-election. This decision came ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. Millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished. The MP was criticized over the loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council when he was leader. About £10.25m of that money is now missing and the loan is subject to a police investigation.

Roy Oliver, 37, fired a rifle into a car, killing Jordan Edwards, 15. The policeman was sacked for policy violations. Roy Oliver fired into a car full of teenagers as they left a party. Police had initially said the vehicle reversed "aggressively" towards the officer, but footage discredited the claim. He was also charged with four counts of aggravated assault. Roy Oliver faces five to 99 years in prison on the murder charge. He is currently free on bail.

The president-elect's wife, Melania Trump, and son, Barron, will move to Washington after Barron finishes the school year. This decision has drawn criticism, but some support it as responsible parenting. Historically, some First Ladies have not lived full-time in the White House. The role of the First Lady is ceremonial, but they often support causes. Melania Trump is interested in tackling cyber-bullying. In the past, other family members have taken on some First Lady duties. Families have found ways to make White House life normal.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been asked to scrutinise the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is "fully engaging" with the investigation. A report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the COPFS in due course.

A yellow wind warning was issued, with gusts up to 75mph possible, especially west of the mountains. The easterly direction of the wind could increase its impact. Travel disruption on roads and at sea is likely. Affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing a main route into the town. Telford Road is expected to be closed most of Monday for cleanup.

The Giants scored first with a goal by Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen tied the game. Mike Forney scored a powerplay goal to make it 2-1, but Andy Bohmback equalized. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored to make it 4-2 before David Ling scored for Nottingham. The teams play again on Saturday. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield with 27 and Belfast with 25.

Hamilton started from the back, had a broken front wing on lap one, and did five pit stops. Vettel came second despite colliding with Raikkonen on the first lap. Raikkonen finished fifth. Ricciardo had a puncture on lap three. Rosberg won the race. Hamilton had three stops within the first six laps. Hamilton's car was damaged in an incident with Nasr.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality to advance discussion of the topic in German football. His announcement was praised by former teammates, leading figures in German football administration, and others. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, which has struggled with homophobia in football. There is hope that his announcement will lead to greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season to help the Seagulls achieve promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring, the midfielder is hoping to sign a new deal. Brighton's recent win over Wigan confirmed their promotion. Sidwell made 19 appearances for Albion on loan from Stoke during 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal with Brighton in June 2016. He has previously played in the Premier League with multiple teams.

Blackpool scored first with a goal from Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized with a goal from Kurtis Guthrie. The game ended in a 1-1 draw. Colchester's Sean Murray received a red card in injury time.

The 29-year-old made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One. Reid could make his debut for the U's in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

PC Keith Palmer's murder prompted a greater need for a permanent memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust appealed for £1.5m towards its construction at the National Memorial Arboretum. The memorial will bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff. The memorial will be dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of officers who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for it and it is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United are 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. They have won 25 of their first 30 matches. Their next league game is against Manchester City. Manchester United have won 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games. Ferguson will make changes for Monday's FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries.

Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Mr. Schmidt said it was up to the government to change its tax system if it wanted companies to pay more taxes. Margaret Hodge has suggested a new committee should be established to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms. Google is criticized for organizing their tax affairs in ways that minimize the amounts they pay in the UK. European Union leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities".

NHS Improvement wants the NHS to reduce its agency bill by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap was introduced in October, saving £600m so far. Hospitals should not be paying more than 55% above normal shift rates for staff, excluding senior managers. The aim is to reduce the cost of agency staff and reliance on them. NHS trusts are 10% down on where they wanted to be. NHS Improvement will publish league tables of best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending and collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust.

The Longford Town Centre, once intended to be a "cathedral of commerce," is now a monument to the end of the Celtic Tiger and Ireland's economic crash. Local traders are seeing a slow turnaround, with businesses like Matt O'Brien's clothing shop seeing an increase in business. Fianna Fáil criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, while the government highlights the planned Center Parcs development in Ballymahon. Local traders believe more could be done to boost local business, such as free parking.

The competition finishes on 29 May. Eight teams face each other twice, with the top four qualifying for the play-offs. Warner (294) is the leading run-scorer, and McClenaghan (9) has the most wickets. Four current or former England players are taking part.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs found the number of plastic carrier bags had gone up by 200 million since 2013. Many of these bags can't be recycled and end up in rubbish dumps and rivers. From October, people in England will have to pay 5p for plastic bags. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland have seen a decrease in bags used after charging for them.

A school roof was ripped off in Rhosgadfan, and hundreds of homes in Wales experienced power cuts. There were train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges. The highest gusts of wind were recorded on Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey. Irish Ferries cancelled six fast sailings, and Arriva Trains Wales warned of speed restrictions and possible delays. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge were lifted Friday evening. Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed to December 27th.

Jordan is "super excited" to work on the film and wants "to put a different spin on it". He will reunite with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. He is looking forward to working with Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan played the Human Torch in Fantastic Four. Nyong'o played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther will be released in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875, is hoped to be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired and refurbished. If successful in raising funds it is hoped the theatre will reopen in 2018. The theatre and studios form part of a larger east wing restoration project. The glazed east court will become a space for the public and for exhibitions. Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) is contributing £18.8m, Haringey Council is contributing £6.8m, and Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust have committed to raising the final £1m. The entire east wing will be refurbished at a cost of £26.6m. The theatre still has much of its original decor and stage machinery in place.

The 30-year-old former Manchester City player won 61 caps for England after his senior debut in 2009. He was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships, playing three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He scored his first international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by a fire. The family escaped, but their dog and cats died. The fire was started by rubbish burned in the wood stove. David, Mrs. Smith's son, was the only one awake and alerted the family to the fire. The community has donated clothes, shoes, and a bike to the family.

An energy drinks giant was considering a £200m offer for the Premier League club. Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in West Ham in 2010, valuing the club at £105m. They now own more than 85% of the club. West Ham has been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan said a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts but he and Gold intend the ownership to pass to their children.

The awards ceremony included fan-voted awards like best kiss and best shirtless performance. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, and Shailene Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper. Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods. Kevin Hart won the comedic genius award. Robert Downey Jr. won the Generation Award. Clips from upcoming movies were shown.

Smith, 21, was loaned to United in July and has five goals this season. He debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren's boss Jack Ross said Smith is a good player and a good fit for the team. St Mirren host Falkirk on Saturday.
Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes each day for the next four months. Extra staff will also repair drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

In December, Wood Group contractors on EnQuest's Thistle platform were exposed to alpha radiation while removing pipework. The workers were not wearing proper PPE because it was assumed the area was clear. EnQuest said the exposure was low and they have taken additional precautions. Wood Group said they are committed to employee safety. The Unite union believes the workers were treated terribly. The HSE was made aware of the incident but it was not reportable.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from Art of the Past in 2007. The company's manager later admitted selling stolen Indian antiquities. The sculpture is thought to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. The decision to return the item came after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ACM bought 30 objects from the art dealer, but none of the others are thought to be listed as stolen. The museum will take legal action to get compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt as far away as Milan and Florence. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The quake struck at 15:48 (14:48 GMT), with its epicenter in Garfagnana. Several aftershocks were felt. Phone lines were down and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. In Milan, top floors of tall office blocks shook. In Lucca, people poured out into the streets. Last May, two earthquakes in the same area left more than 20 people dead. The latest tremor "came out of nowhere", and was described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow". Italy is still trying to recover from the aftermath of the deadly earthquake in L'Aquila.
On September 8, 2016, Austin Grant from Sheffield was happy to see fruit growing on his plant, although it is not yet ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar has delayed the game's release until March 24. The game was originally due to go on sale on January 27. Online heists are coming to consoles before the PC release date. Screenshots from the PC version have been released, with Rockstar promising "even greater levels of detail". Minimum specifications required to run the game have also been published. Grand Theft Auto V became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever when it was released on September 17, 2013.

The 76-year-old artist won the £25,000 prize for Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The artist was shortlisted in 1991 and has been on the longlist three other times. Squint (19) depicts a leper squint, which are holes in medieval churches for undesirables to view the service. The artist said the prize money would be spent on art supplies. The John Moores Painting Prize is a biennial art award established in 1957.

The offices of Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked by masked assailants. No casualties were reported. The Yeni Safak building was attacked by four masked assailants and a fire was quickly extinguished. Windows in both buildings were shattered by gunfire and spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. The two papers support the governing AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The Yeni Akit offices are 20km away from the Yeni Safak building, and the attacks happened almost at the same time. Police are hunting the assailants. No group has claimed responsibility.

A 24-year-old player under contract with the Stags will join Marcus Bignot's side on a free transfer. He was previously on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. The player will officially join on January 1 and is Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Wenger has been linked with a job. Southgate succeeded Sam Allardyce in September. Southgate has a World Cup qualifier against Scotland and a friendly against Spain to persuade the Football Association to give him the job on a permanent basis. Wenger said that Hector Bellerin would be offered a new contract by the club. Aaron Ramsey will miss "one or two" more games.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police is carrying out a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive. The company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf said a new charter arrangement would end the row over seafarers' pay. The RMT union claimed some workers on board two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will see contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month. The freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay have been operated by Seatruck. Serco Northlink said it had repeatedly offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined to accept. The new arrangements would come into force early next month and all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink was awarded the six-year £243m Northern Isles contract in 2012.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother. Mr. Mitchell and his mother, Samantha, 57, also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton died in London at age 66 after a battle with cancer. He wrote hits such as "Off The Wall", "Baby Be Mine", "Boogie Nights", and "Thriller". He was nicknamed The Invisible Man due to his low profile. He was influenced by his father and Radio Luxembourg. He joined the band Heatwave and later wrote songs for Michael Jackson. He won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986.

A team including Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, found ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in the western Brazilian Amazon. The research investigated ditched enclosures, or "geoglyphs", which were concealed for centuries by rainforest. The function of these sites is still little understood, but it is thought they were used sporadically, perhaps as ritual gathering places. The geoglyphs were constructed amongst taller vegetation and were likely not visible above the forest canopy. The research indicates a wide variety of plant species spread over 6,000 years, which could only have been artificially brought together by humans. It is suggested that people transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees.

Australian Kyrgios, 21, beat Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to progress to the second round. Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, won the Japan Open on Sunday. Kyrgios said he was tired and bored. He said his success in Japan and the travelling had taken its toll. Last year at the Shanghai Masters, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst.

The HPV vaccine, currently given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer, is being called to be rolled out to protect against head and neck cancers. Charities and scientists are urging the Welsh government to vaccinate boys, as head and neck cancer cases are increasing, with three-quarters of those affected being men with an average age of 55. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.

Jak Trueman, 15, had a rare form of blood cancer and documented his life and treatment on social media. He briefly attended a school prom held in his honor before passing away. His story touched many people and his Facebook page, Jak's Journey, attracted more than 28,000 likes. He received the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. After finding out his cancer had spread, he and his family urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.
Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 with a late goal by El Said, assisted by Salah. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside. Egypt will play Ghana next, while Uganda is out of the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has chosen the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College as the location for a new railway station. The council plans for two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The location was chosen after a comparative study and is big enough for future expansion. The council will now start acquiring the land. Skelmersdale is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without a railway station.
Police found plants in an elaborate grow house in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets in Hamelin. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, handed himself in to authorities. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is not yet clear.

A study of 4,600 workers found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but men are 25% more likely to get one. The study found no evidence that women were reluctant to ask for a pay rise or were more wary of upsetting their boss. The study also found that women and men under 40 both ask for and receive pay rises at the same rate.

Oxford City Council used money for ground investigations of possible burial sites but found none suitable. Two cemeteries have space but are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council is still exploring options. They have been searching for a suitable new burial site for many years but have run out of suitable land within Oxford. All council-owned sites have been discounted due to size, ground conditions, a high water table, or a covenant. After the two remaining cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, the use of a few reserved plots, and the interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Visitors can use an app to trigger online information from signs and posters, including videos and band interviews. The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean are among this year's acts. The app will allow people around the world to interact with the festival and access information, interviews, and buy tickets.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Episodes such as this are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, but had never collapsed before. He had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

In 2004, a 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage. The defendant, now 34 and called Davina, denied the charge. She will be sentenced on 4 March and remanded into custody at a male prison. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted to commit suicide last summer. In 2012, she changed her name. Portsmouth Crown Court was told she raped the teenager while two others were asleep in the garage. The victim said she shouted at Ayrton to stop the attack. In 2014, Ayrton told a worker at the care home where she lived about the attack.

The Serbs lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss came a day after Djokovic was knocked out of the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic suffered a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July when he lost to American Sam Querrey. The 12-time Grand Slam winner came back to claim his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors will participate in Saturday's event in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms. Carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada and the US will compete using only chainsaws to carve logs into the shapes of animals and people. Last year's winner Pete Bowsher will return to defend his title.

Webb has not played since suffering a foot injury in September. He is close to a return and hopes to be fit for the Six Nations in February. He has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union. Wales begin their Six Nations campaign away to Ireland on Sunday, 7 February.

On Tuesday morning, border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near Sumas, Washington. The men were attempting to smuggle MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One man fired a weapon at the agents and ran, while the other was taken into custody. The fugitive was later arrested in British Columbia. The backpacks contained 58lb of ecstasy. A woman and her boyfriend were also arrested for planning to transport the drugs. The area is a known smuggling route.

Childline counselled more than 4,500 children in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. Some children as young as seven told Childline how they were tormented, abused and scared to go to school. Cyber-bullying can follow children home until it becomes a persecution they cannot escape. Adults, parents and teachers, must intervene to protect them. Schools must take this problem seriously, and children must ask for help.

Following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office, a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in settlements was postponed. This comes before a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The US abstained from a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which infuriated Mr. Netanyahu. The resolution stated that the establishment of settlements has no legal validity and is a violation of international law. Israel rejected the resolution and responded by summoning ambassadors and recalling its own ambassadors to some countries.

The Queen's 90th birthday was marked with several events, including a visit to a Royal Mail delivery office, the opening of a new bandstand, and the release of commemorative stamps. Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. He also addressed criticisms of being "work-shy," stating he takes his responsibilities seriously but is developing into his role. The Queen's birthday celebrations included the unveiling of a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway and the lighting of beacons. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Cheltenham had some chances, but West Ham controlled the game, making seven changes to their lineup. The match was the second meeting between the two sides in the competition, with West Ham winning the first meeting 2-1.

Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a motorcycle crash on the A5. Andreas Werner, 46, failed to spot McNicholl and caused the crash. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not want Werner to be jailed.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from London, is considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from conflict. He was a public fighter in Syria, part of Rayat al Tawheed, and was involved in producing propaganda videos. He faked his death and tried to sneak back into the UK, but was arrested and is facing a possible life sentence.
Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season. He is Barnsley's third signing for next season. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham.

Bottles of Vanish have been washing up on the Cornish coast, posing a risk to wildlife. The National Trust believes a container went overboard from a ship during stormy weather. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency said there is no evidence the bottles are from the MV Blue Ocean, which lost a container of Vanish in May. Other nearby coves have also been affected. Cornwall Wildlife Trust is concerned about the impact on marine life. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles.

The incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00. Several other people received minor injuries in the crash. The road was closed and diversions were put in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland said inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, 28, made 14 appearances last season to help Wanderers get promoted. The French centre-back joined Bolton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances. Manager Phil Parkinson said Dervite made an excellent contribution. Dervite follows David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan in signing new contracts with Bolton.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being prepared to "concede everything," and Labour's Baroness Smith responded that his party was giving people "false hope." The two parties had previously cooperated to inflict defeats on the government concerning the rights of EU citizens and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but that cooperation ended when MPs rejected those amendments. A Labour source said the Lib Dems were "grandstanding," while the Lib Dems accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans." The two parties have a track record of forming alliances on other issues, and the Lib Dems say they will continue to work with peers from across the House. However, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions."

Defense is a low priority for most political parties in this election, with public opinion polls showing it is not a major concern. The UK military has been making significant cuts, reducing the size of the army, navy, and air force. The UK has fallen to sixth place in global defense spending and is likely to fall below the NATO threshold of 2% of GDP. There is debate over the renewal of the Trident nuclear deterrent, with varying opinions among political parties. The UK will have two new aircraft carriers, but there are concerns about manning and equipment levels.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost of Neymar will be £106.8m. Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president following accusations he misappropriated money. A judge ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona made a tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches.

Michael Luciw, 27, died when the van he was a passenger in was hit by a car driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Luciw's family believes retired people should have regular driving tests, while Age UK says it is vital older people can drive for as long as possible. The crash occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire. The driver of the van, Andy Harrington, sustained serious injuries and believes retired drivers should have medical examinations. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must fill in a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, but the DVLA has no plans to restrict licensing based on age.

Many women have suffered debilitating side effects from mesh implants used to treat incontinence. Two patients quit the original review group in protest of a watered-down report. Independent expert Alison Britton will examine the final report. The report concluded procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended patients be offered a range of treatments and given the information to make "informed choices". Reporting of adverse events should be mandatory. The government does not have the power to ban the procedures. The chairwoman of the independent review apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the review's final report. Two patients quit the review group earlier this year, saying they felt "dismayed and disgusted" at the publication of the independent report. Over the past 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants and some have suffered painful and debilitating complications. There are more than 400 women currently taking legal action.

Muir, 23, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan had concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria for record-breaking attempts, but British Athletics confirmed Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. McColgan said Muir has the ability to run faster and win world medals. McColgan also said Muir's race was similar to her own record-breaking race 25 years ago.
Jung won gold, Nicolas took silver, and Dutton won bronze. Fox-Pitt finished 12th after a disappointing cross-country performance. Evans finished ninth.

Murray won his match against Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in two hours and 39 minutes, clinching match point at 20:57 BST. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Johanna Konta also reached the second week with a 6-4 6-1 win. Murray said the match was tense and he didn't feel like it was his best tennis. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set but Murray won five games in a row to win.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 for a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, and James Thomas, 44, faced one count. The judge said Ms. O'Neill had an appalling record and fined her £3,000, while Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt said "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." The Ulster Unionists want the election to be a referendum on how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled. Mr. Nesbitt said he would rather go into Stormont with the SDLP than Sinn Fein. The manifesto, entitled 'Real Partnership', includes calls for action in tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritising the York Street interchange, standing up for the LGBT community and "guaranteeing" that no group is worse off because of Brexit. The party calls for "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption" to be addressed.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will go before the assembly for approval to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales, where plans for automatic pardons were announced last month. The motion will allow for pardons both posthumously as well as for living gay and bisexual men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. The minister said she has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offences.

Laura Muir, 23, finished second behind Faith Kipyegon in 4:19.12, breaking the Scottish record of 4:22.60 set by Yvonne Murray in 1994. Muir now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records. She hopes to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham from 24 to 26 June.
The passage states that there are pictures from 26 beaches ranked as Scotland's "most excellent" for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC said suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Mr. Litvinenko. The Russian state is likely to have been the sponsor of the plot. Mr. Litvinenko was poisoned with polonium-210 and died in hospital nearly three weeks later. The evidence suggests the Russian state was involved in Mr. Litvinenko's murder. Mr. Horwell said the risk to the general public in London from polonium radiation will never be known. The suspects left a "trail of polonium" behind and they had "no credible answer" to the scientific evidence against them. Attempts to extradite the two men have failed and they remain in Russia.

Steve Smith, 26, will captain the Twenty20 team and the one-day side, with David Warner, 28, as his vice-captain. Smith was appointed after Michael Clarke, 34, retired. Smith has played in 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Warner has matured and developed into an important senior figure. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches that follow the final Ashes Test.

Mr. Farron refused to answer if he believed homosexual sex was a sin, but said he was "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and defending equal marriage would be "at the top of my agenda". He also wants to extend the marital rights of transgender people. He voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about "protection of individual liberties".

Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare will now use the plant for pharmaceutical production, hoping to fill many jobs with ex-Sanofi staff. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the area. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company that develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to about 60 countries.

Richard Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract on Friday. Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are going under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn said the departures were indicative of the council's inability to hold on to senior staff and he expects further departures. Mr. Ellis is the council's former interim director of corporate governance and has also been acting as deputy chief executive. Mr. Monaghan is head of the chief executive's office, while Mr. Sutherland is head of human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their "dedication and professionalism".

The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has had mechanical problems. Martin said he was quitting road racing but later clarified he has no plans to do anymore road racing on the Hondas this year. Martin didn't race at the North West 200 and will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix. He said the TT was a disaster and the bike won't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix. He wants to race classics and oddball stuff.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The APC also won the presidential poll last month, and leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost for the first time in key northern states and lost control of Adamawa. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC has made historic gains, relegating the PDP to a regional party. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states. The elections were marred by violence in some areas. The APC retained power in Lagos state.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, accuses Olam and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to haze caused by fires. Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third party suppliers and says it has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy. Temasek has dismissed the allegations, stating they do not direct the business operations of their portfolio companies. The palm oil industry is often accused of unfair labor practices, deforestation, and burning of plantations. Mighty also claims Olam is responsible for forest clearings in Gabon. Olam says its private-public partnerships in Gabon are responsible and transparent.
On August 27, 2016, a restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors.
Forward Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to a knee injury. Derby County striker David Nugent could return from a groin injury. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the ban on YouTube because Google launched a Pakistan-specific version. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directed internet service providers to open access to YouTube. Google will restrict access to offending material for users within Pakistan, but government requests for removal of content will not automatically be granted. The ban was imposed in 2012 after the film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded. Google launched local versions of YouTube for Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, as is presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Musa Bility says he will go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, as he believes Scala has a conflict of interest. Scala's spokesman says there is no conflict of interest. The election to replace Blatter will take place in 18 days.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments on Monday, shortly after 09:00 BST. They were working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A flashover explosion, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition, is believed to be the cause. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations for complaints against Caf, but apologized and was allowed to participate. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup but was allowed to enter after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban. Morocco was previously punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola fears. Tunisia was upset by a controversial penalty in their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea, leading to their complaints. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was secured after a meeting with Caf.

In the 95th minute of a game Chelsea won 3-1, a mass fracas occurred. City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, while Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, and Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales and other parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world. A pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Neath is focusing on patients whose GPs suspect cancer but who do not show any urgent signs or symptoms. This comes a year after doctors visited Denmark to see their diagnostic systems, which have improved cancer survival rates. The concern is that patients in Wales without clear symptoms wait too long for a diagnosis. 40 doctors in Cwm Cynon will be able to refer patients to a diagnostic center within seven days. It is estimated that about six patients a week will be seen and have different tests, hopefully on the same day. A similar clinic will be set up in Neath Port Talbot Hospital. The trials have been developed in the 12 months since experts from Wales returned from Aarhus. If the Cwm Cynon pilot scheme is successful, the rest of the health boards in the area will offer the same service in the following months.

England won against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, resulting in their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. Pakistan were bowled out for 198 and 234.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, and Rob Howley is part of his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will be head coach for the third time after leading Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The WRU will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. The involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team.

Southampton took an early lead with a penalty, but Hull came back to win 2-1 with goals from Snodgrass and Dawson. Hull had two players injured in the first half, but Snodgrass's introduction changed the game. Southampton pushed for an equalizer, but Hull's goalkeeper and defense held strong. This win ends Hull's six-game losing streak.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist lived locally. The tractor driver was not injured. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, saying he wanted to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. This move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials. The crisis was sparked by covert recordings which appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev said the move was illegal. EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn said the move put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Saturday's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea wants to appoint a new boss quickly, with Paul Clement as the first choice. Curtis believes Swansea has lost their way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 and that the current squad is good enough to stay up. He reminds new signings of the club's history.

Dagenham lost to Orient, resulting in their relegation to the National League. Dagenham had reached League One in 2010, and the Football League for the first time in 2007. They have the worst goal difference in League Two and have struggled in attack. Orient's victory keeps their play-off hopes alive.

The former Reds captain, 36, will return to his former club as a youth coach in February. Klopp said he had a good long chat with the ex-England skipper, who wants to be a manager in the future. Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and left Anfield at the end of the 2014-15 season. He retired as a player in November after a 19-year career. He is also working towards his Uefa A coaching licence.
McManus scored to open the scoring, Ross Forbes doubled the lead, Kyle McAusland pulled Alloa back into the game, and McManus and Denny Johnstone scored to ensure a win for the hosts.

Ofsted found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three places in Birmingham, which have now closed. Anyone running illegal schools could face a jail term of up to 51 weeks. Ministers are consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. A total of 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been visited as part of an investigation. Any place where children are taught for more than 20 hours a week has to register as a school. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools. The education secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. It is the first new distillery in the Borders in nearly 200 years. The gin production is on a small scale, using a small still and fitting into a cowshed. Lilliard Gin aims to capture the local flavor using wild food from the Teviot valley. The gin is named after a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who was the heroine of the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam died after Gary Green reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure the safety of others. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation because the incident occurred on private land.

Uruguay striker Luis Suarez can now train and play in friendly matches for Barcelona. His public presentation as a new Barcelona player will be on Monday. He is still banned from "organized" matches, but can participate in all "football-related activities". He will still serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games. His competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be at Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez's lawyers argued that FIFA's decision to suspend him from all football-related activity was too strong a punishment. CAS confirmed the sanctions imposed by FIFA but said preventing Suarez from taking part in any football activity was "excessive".

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna beat Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania in a race where competitors must tackle a 380-metre course, hurdling over haystacks, scrabbling up a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. You don't need to be married to take part. Rich and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond said job roles would change when the paper system for car tax discs is scrapped in October. The new system will allow people to pay the charge by monthly direct debit. Any reductions in numbers of people needed will be managed through redeploying to other growth areas of the business.

Hungary's government is facing pressure from the EU to withdraw three laws regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers and NGOs, as well as a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University. Hungary has stated they will not backtrack on these issues, and Poland would veto any EU sanctions against Hungary.

The star will play Mrs Potts, Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and the film will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will play Gaston. Josh Gad will play LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Columnist Adrian Gill was diagnosed with cancer and died. He was described as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the Sunday Times. Gill was known for his wit, writing, and intelligence. He was a controversial figure, with some of his articles causing outrage. He was also known for his dyslexia, which led him to dictate his copy over the phone. Gill was married twice and had four children.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator, reportedly hit with a bottle and kicked in the face. He was wearing a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika, a symbol that pre-dates Hitler. His father said he was in a coma for 10 days after the beating. A Russian official is accused of the attack, but has not been identified. The Russian embassy is investigating, calling local press reports "distorted". The rapper's lawyer denied reports that he shouted "Heil Hitler" at the show. A police spokesman said the suspect is a Russian diplomatic officer and the case is under investigation.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid protested airport expansion plans on Monday. They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. They will appear in court on 19 August. The protest took place on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday. Airport security will be reviewed.

Nick Selman scored 101 for Glamorgan, his second first-class century. Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets for Gloucestershire. Glamorgan's innings also included 36 runs from Aneurin Donald. Glamorgan reached a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire struggled in the evening. Michael Hogan is leading Glamorgan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph. Matt Taylor was happy with his bowling performance.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He admitted to planning a false report to the police so that officers would come to the scene, where he would then shoot them. The threats were made on two occasions while Hughes was drunk. He had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was on bail awaiting trial for firearms offences at the time.

After being reduced to 8-2, Surrey posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes (90) sharing a stand of 130. Yorkshire's run-chase was undermined by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker. Tim Bresnan made 68 but was the last to go as they were all out for 236. Yorkshire were hoping to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002. Matthew Waite dropped Davies, then on 43, off his own bowling. Davies went on to hit a six and 10 fours before finally falling to Waite. After losing Adam Lyth early, Yorkshire were well-placed on 75-2, but Meaker turned the game on its head by ripping out Bairstow, Ballance and Leaning. Bresnan and Waite did their best to repair the damage, but 27 off the final three overs was too much.

A 56ft converted trawler was 6 miles west of South Stack when the crew radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST. A pump on board the boat was unable to cope with the water coming in. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir will not be with the Scotland team at next year's event on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies. Her exams are in May, and the Commonwealths are in April. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. The World Indoor Championships in March are "potentially a target".

Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's decline since last season, their struggles in the transfer market, and their lack of goals. He also analyzes their defensive issues and the physical and mental challenges Steven Gerrard faces. Savage predicts a Chelsea win and believes Gerrard still has a future with Liverpool.

A £45m facility will be built in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The council will ask the McIlvanney family to name the campus in his honor. William McIlvanney was a writer born and educated in Kilmarnock, who was also an English teacher before becoming a full-time writer. He is known for his Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works, and was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster. He died on December 5th.

An area of the town near the swimming pool was evacuated due to a sea mine spotted on Monday. The mine is thought to be British, dating from the 1940s or 1950s. The evacuation affected three streets, with wider safety advice issued to residents within 500m of the device. There was also an exclusion zone at sea of about half a mile. Ferry services were disrupted. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and there was no immediate danger to the community. The mine was moved to a safer place before being dealt with.

UK Sport will invest £345m in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, £2m less than the amount allocated for the Rio Games. Team GB is set a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Cycling has had its funding cut by more than £4m, and badminton's funding has been removed despite winning a bronze medal in Rio. Judo, which also won a bronze medal, has had its funding increased slightly. Basketball, handball, and volleyball have had their funding withdrawn in previous years. Funding for the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed.

Three Victorian hotels will be demolished to make way for a six-storey hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage objected to the scale of the development, but councillors voted in favor, saying it would help tourism. The site will get a 90-room hotel along with a nine-storey and seven-storey building, comprising 122 assisted-living apartments. The council received 246 letters supporting the plans and 49 letters objecting.

Pte Matthew Boyd was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely in Brecon. Vallely was found guilty, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter. Pte Boyd was found unconscious by police after being beaten outside a bar. Vallely had been drinking for seven hours and boasted he was the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack.
