The family of Pte Boyd described him as "loving, caring and loyal" and said Vallely had created "a void in our family that will never be filled".

Andrew Travers left his position by "mutual agreement" after an error where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes. The council's review will conclude by the end of May.

Josh Gillies scored a free-kick for Gateshead, and Sean Newton scored a free-kick for Wrexham to tie the game. Ryan Bowman scored a header for Gateshead to win the game. The final score was Gateshead 2, Wrexham 1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of those over 60 in 96 countries. Norway is ranked the best and Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project aims to deliver broadband links globally using a network of at least 600 satellites, potentially expanding to over 2,000. This requires a shift to high-volume, low-cost satellite manufacturing, using assembly line methods similar to car and plane factories. Airbus and OneWeb have established assembly lines in France and Florida, with plans to launch the first 10 satellites in April of next year. The project will use over 20 Soyuz vehicles to launch clusters of satellites, aiming for nearly 300 satellites by the end of 2020/start of 2021, over 600 a year later, and over 800 by the middle of the decade. OneWeb is also focused on debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit satellites within two years and adding hardware for reliable de-orbiting.

Mr. Swinney said the UK government's recent spending review placed "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland. The UK government said Scottish ministers would have £390m more in spending available to them next year. The Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. Mr. Swinney said schools, hospitals and the police service in Scotland would "not be sacrificed to the chancellor's austerity obsession". A spokesman for the UK government's Scotland Office said the Scottish government will have £390m more spending available to it next year, which rises to £750m if you include its own underspend.

Many people with severe disabilities and their carers face challenges when leaving the house due to a lack of suitable toilet facilities. Standard accessible toilets are often inadequate for those needing assistance from two carers or a hoist. Changing Places toilets, which have enhanced features and more space, are recommended for larger buildings, but campaigners want them to be compulsory. There are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but potentially over a quarter of a million people need them. The lack of these facilities can be isolating and psychologically damaging for families. While some businesses face logistical and financial barriers to installing these toilets, some have found ways to adapt and provide them.

Italian consumer organizations have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's claims it shares risks and rewards with its licensees. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the complaint. The European Commission will study the submission and has the power to launch an investigation. The consumer organizations claim franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to long contracts and lease premises from the company at above market rates. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe. McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A poster with the phrase #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood. It is part of a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church and has gone viral. A mystery donor paid for the billboard. There has been a huge outpouring of support on Twitter for Joshua.

The UK military is undergoing a shake-up of buildings and resettling of regiments. Brecon Barracks, which has been in Brecon since 1805, is closing. A specialist light infantry centre will be created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. Cawdor Barracks will shut in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will go in 2025.

A House of Lords report says that the UK fishing industry, which only produces a half of one percent of GDP and employs 12,000 fishers, must not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The report states that the UK may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal. The majority of UK fish are exported, mainly to the EU, while a significant proportion of the fish that British consumers eat is imported, often from EU states. The report also points out that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas should continue to be based on scientific advice.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked documents revealing the US National Security Agency (NSA) has access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The US government also requested millions of phone records from Verizon. Prism enabled "backdoor" access to the servers of nine major technology companies. The US government argues these operations are necessary for national security, while others raise concerns about privacy. User data is often stored in the US, giving American authorities power over it. It is unknown if other governments are involved.

Open AI is backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys and Amazon Web Services. Its research will focus on a "positive human impact". Some scientists, including Musk and Stephen Hawking, have warned that AI could threaten humanity. Other experts believe the risk of AI posing a threat is remote. OpenAI aims to advance digital intelligence to benefit humanity, unconstrained by financial return. They believe AI should be an extension of human wills and broadly distributed. Only a small fraction of the $1bn pledged will be spent in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. He carried the Olympic torch on 26 June and has received thousands of Facebook friend requests, but the site limits friend associations to 5,000. He walks with crutches and spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab. He also raises money for military charities and is a patron of Pilgrim Bandits. His mother said the responses have been phenomenal and that Ben was really buoyed up by the support. Facebook suggests he should consider having a page instead of a profile. 8,000 people will carry the flame during its 8,000 mile, 70-day journey to the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in London on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans in poverty. Real median household income dropped by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality increased by 1.6%. The percentage of Americans lacking health insurance fell to 15.7%. Poverty in the US reached a record high in 2010, at 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, 25, moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013 and is now tied to the club until 2019. He has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries. Cricket director Ashley Giles said Buttler is one of the most talented cricketers and his presence was a factor in winning last year's T20 Blast final. Buttler will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the ships. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Viewings are set to take place in late February and March, with a final decision expected in the spring. The government wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler. Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, would like to see at least one of them saved from the scrapyard, with a preference for a reef and diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence will "consider all options" for the frigates to ensure "best financial return for the taxpayer". The Type 22 frigate was originally designed as a specialist anti-submarine ship, but evolved into a powerful surface combatant.

Since 1987, racial and political tensions have caused instability and international isolation in Fiji. A coup in 1987 by indigenous Fijians overthrew the elected, Indian-dominated coalition. A further coup in 2000 saw the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister held hostage. These events harmed the economy and Fiji's international reputation. In 2006, there was a military takeover, Fiji's fourth coup in 20 years. In 2009, Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth. In 2012, the government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, and Fiji was reinstated as a member of the Commonwealth. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. The economy relies on sugar and tourism, but is diverse. Fiji has been hampered by trade and budget deficits.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister said Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, but a shipment of weapons was attacked twice. He also said the US is supporting terrorist elements and denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims 246 people have been killed in Aleppo in the last five days alone after barrel bombs were dropped by military helicopters. The US said that only about 4% of Syria's chemical weapons stockpile has left the country. Russia has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast by March 1. The OPCW has admitted the process has been slowed down by security concerns.

The Booker Prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality, for the first time this year. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The shortlist includes three British writers, two Americans, and an Australian. Mukherjee's "The Lives Of Others" is the favorite to win. Other shortlisted authors include Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan. The best-selling book on the list is Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves". The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling. Last year's winner was Eleanor Catton.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing against a court ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media. The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant an appeal. An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS. PJS argues he has a right to privacy. The court ruled that PJS had "occasional sexual encounters" with another person, AB, starting in 2009, including a three-way encounter with AB and CD. The story had been published in the US, Scotland and elsewhere, and had spread across the internet. The judges ruled that PJS was now unlikely to get a permanent injunction as confidentiality had "probably been lost".

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was bought in August for £345.5m. Plans are being prepared to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. The new owners met with the council to clear up "potential planning questions". The new owners want to address parking and congestion issues and believe the park has become rather tired. They are concerned with the quality of common areas and facilities.

The film was held for a "review" in Malaysia due to a "gay moment". The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the screening with a minor edit to the gay moment. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia. The film was granted a "P13 parental guidance classification". Local cinema chains are offering refunds for purchased tickets. The "gay moment" involves LeFou and his feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film has been criticized.

Landlords who let properties to more than three unrelated people need a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) license, which can cost £1,000. Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Nationally, mandatory licensing for HMOs is aimed at houses of three storeys or more and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licenses affect properties in certain areas. The council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil hope to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government, but not support a programme for government. Water charges are a main issue, with Fianna Fáil wanting their removal and Fine Gael seeing a role for them. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and the Labour Party got seven. No party was able to form a majority government.

The Sorrento caught fire while traveling to Valencia, and passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship. At least three people were injured and taken to the hospital. The fire broke out on one of the car decks about 27km from Mallorca. The cause of the fire is unknown. The rescued passengers boarded the Puglia and were on their way to Palma de Mallorca. The Sorrento may sink. The ferry sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs highlighted people claiming to have voted twice, which is a criminal offense. They stated that individual electoral registers should be better connected to identify duplicate entries. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the June 8th election, with 68.7% voter turnout. There was a surge in applications to register, with 2.9 million received over six weeks. Duplicate applications were a concern, with an estimated 30-70% in some areas. The watchdog said this caused administrative and financial burdens and should be addressed. They also said that people registered in two seats should choose which one they will vote in at future general elections. Labour warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, killed himself early on Wednesday. He was a star player at the University of Nebraska in the 1990s and played in the NFL until 1999. After his NFL career, he had problems with the law and was sent to prison for assault. He was accused of killing his former cellmate and was found to have enough evidence to be tried in the death.

Private Derby XXX was promoted to lance corporal by Brigadier Andrew Williams for "good behaviour". He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams and joined the regiment in February 2014. He has his own army number, gets paid to buy his rations and takes his holidays during the mating season. He has also helped switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a dramatic match, with a late goal by Dejan Lovren. The victory was inspired by the spirit of the 2005 Champions League final. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp emphasized the importance of belief and the team's refusal to give up. The match was played in an electric atmosphere at Anfield, with both sets of fans creating a memorable experience. Liverpool's performance showcased their growing confidence and the impact of Klopp's leadership.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, Mr. Davis said the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland up-to-date about negotiations. Mr. Russell said transparency about UK government plans was needed. Mr. Davis said he wanted to hold a monthly meeting to share analysis. Mr. Russell said the UK government has not made its strategic intentions clear and that membership of the single market is essential for the economic prosperity of Scotland. The Scottish government will seek to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal.

Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr is examining Daisy the sheep, a clone, for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. Daisy is one of 13 cloned sheep, four of which are from the same cell line as Dolly the sheep. Researchers are studying these sheep to determine if cloned animals age normally and if they are more prone to diseases associated with aging. The study focuses on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study will be published next week.

Shutter Speed won the Musidora, her fifth win for both Gosden and Dettori. She will go to Chantilly next, rather than the Oaks at Epsom. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes. Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes.

The currency initially slipped against the dollar and euro, then recovered before falling again. The "volatility index" hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar, 0.6% against the euro, and 1% against the Japanese yen. Investors were spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote have fallen. Two polls put the Leave camp ahead, and the implied probability of a vote to Remain fell to 68.5%. Markets are on full Brexit alert, and sterling has shed more than 2% in two sessions. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1%.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. Barrow extended their unbeaten league run to nine games with the victory. Braintree's losing run extended to three games. Cowley said what they've done so far has been remarkable.

The most controversial move is putting politicians in charge of all but the most significant planning decisions. From April 2015, councils will be able to accept or reject developments in their own areas. Michael Corr believes this is a huge opportunity for the future. However, Friends of the Earth warn that a strict code of conduct will have to be rigorously enforced to ensure fairness and transparency. Some local politicians are opposed to the move, because they say it could deter donors worried about their personal security.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, which had to be amputated. The Scottish SPCA is urging the Scottish government to implement the licensing of airguns. Last year the Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons, but a majority of responders opposed the plan.

Benteke is Liverpool's second most expensive signing on a long-term contract. Liverpool triggered a release clause in Benteke's contract to make him their seventh summer signing. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa. Liverpool struggled for goals last season and have added Benteke to revive their attack. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup with an Achilles tendon injury but returned to action last October and scored 15 times.

A study found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablets, despite their increasing use in schools. Tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% of schools having a tablet for every pupil. The study also found that many pupils take internet-connected devices to bed for social media. While a definitive connection between tablets and improved results cannot be made, head teachers reported a positive impact, and tablets help motivate pupils and increase family involvement. A separate study suggested touch-screen computers were useful in helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read.

The Growing Up in the City exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs of children's lives in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. The photographs show how much life for a child has changed, and also depict special occasions. The exhibition includes images of children at play, as well as children at work. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, who chose the final 25 images from hundreds of images from the National Museums Liverpool's collections. The exhibition is at the Museum of Liverpool until 25 September.

Anderson, 27, a centre-back, has cancelled his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson. Anderson could play against his old club on 18 February. Keating has previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone.

Bolivian law permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization. The law also sets a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The law was signed by Mr. Garcia in the absence of President Evo Morales. More than 500,000 children work in Bolivia. The International Labour Organisation says children under 15 should not work, but allows a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries. The ILO is studying the legislation to decide if it breaches international regulations on child labor.

A 50 year-old woman said she was "lucky to be here" after falling ill at home. She searched "women's heart attack symptoms" online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day. The cardiologist inserted a stent into an artery that was 99 percent blocked. She revealed the type of attack was known as the "widow maker". She did not call the emergency services, and issued a warning to her readers to know the symptoms and call 911. She recently hosted The Rosie Show which was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was stabbed and killed at a party in Kenton. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and taken to a hospital. A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder, and two boys aged 15 and 16 were also arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed. A 14-year-old boy is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganized its patient diagnosis approach due to poor cancer survival statistics. The changes included three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with "alarm" symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with undiagnosed symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. These changes have led to better survival rates and improved organization of patient diagnosis.

The UK government disbanded the OFT, and Powys won a competitive bid to deliver the service in its place, receiving £170,000 a year. Powys will issue warning and banning orders against dishonest agents or those breaching estate agent laws. People will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will refer cases to Powys if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong workforce after a Nuffield Trust review found examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. The review highlighted opportunities to improve patient care and provide staff with more rewarding roles, but unions warned against using it as a quick fix for problems in the NHS. The British Medical Association leader said increasing the skills of the workforce should not be done at the expense of good quality training for doctors.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath after a crash at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT, causing disruption to commuters and bus services. Investigations are under way into how the collision happened. First said that while parts of its services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal.

NRW estimated the lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die each year. TLP said the claims had no "clear scientific basis" and that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's computer modeling estimated a "worst case scenario" of the lagoon killing 2% of all species of fish. The £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project is being viewed as a test bed for larger versions. UK government ministers are considering the findings of a six-month review of the scheme. Wales' Environment Secretary said the Welsh Government was "very supportive" of the scheme. NRW said it strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism.

Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced the development of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body. The body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and will provide strategic leadership for marketing activities. Stormont's Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill said that the new body was a positive step but could have implications for other organizations.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a project to plant millions of native UK trees to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. As part of this project, 40,000 trees will be planted at Brackfield Wood in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. Members of the public are invited to participate in the tree planting, and the charity is providing the saplings.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour. The accolades were handed out at the start of the North Yorkshire town's annual crime writing festival. Hilary's winning book is a thriller that tackles domestic violence and so-called honour crime. Sara Paretsky was chosen for the outstanding contribution to crime fiction award after her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski.

Mitch Santner, 24, broke his finger in his second game for the county in 2016. He will rejoin the Rapids after June's ICC Trophy. He enjoyed his time at Worcester but was frustrated to pick up an injury. Worcestershire signed John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008. The coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was 19 years younger than him and tried to claim his assets within days of his death. His family believes he was killed in a staged hit and run accident. The car that hit him had stolen license plates and did not brake or stop. Witnesses described the killing as a deliberate act. The Ukrainian police relaunched an inquiry into his death as a murder inquiry in 2011.

Charlie Fearns of Merseyside needs to fly to Seattle for T-Cell Therapy after his last transplant failed. His mother was overwhelmed by the anonymous donor who paid for his treatment. Charlie has been ill since the age of three and after a third relapse in April there were no treatment options left in the UK. The family was heartbroken when the first transplant did not work. Charlie's father said they were extremely grateful for the donation. They received confirmation via email from the hospital that someone had offered to pay for the treatment. The treatment will start as soon as possible.

Third-party software was used to steal celebrity photos from iCloud. Apple has implemented a two-step verification system that requires a four-digit code after a username and password are entered on a new device. A 14-character recovery key can be used to regain access if a trusted device is lost or stolen. While Apple had offered the two-step verification system in the past, it had not come into play when device owners used the firm's back-up service. Apple plans to encourage people to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves said the "finer points" of a deal which could see Wright buy 20% of the club are yet to be released. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright played non-league football for a succession of clubs. Billericay have recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mr. Ashley was asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation. Mr. Ashley has until March 21 to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright. The letter reveals Mr. Ashley invited the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee to a meeting at the company's base. The committee will be reviewing the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage. The committee normally meets in public at Westminster. Mr. Ashley has not accepted any of the alternative dates offered to him. If Mr. Ashley fails to agree to attend, the committee reserves the right to take the matter further. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for a comment.

The report, "Putin. War," was completed by colleagues of a murdered opposition politician, led by Ilya Yashin. It accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, citing evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment being decisive in rebel victories. The report includes evidence of volunteer soldiers admitting Russian generals directed battles, and that they were paid salaries of $2,000-3,000 a month. Russian spending on the conflict is calculated at 53bn roubles. The opposition will seek donations to extend the initial print run of 2,000 copies.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The 34-year-old from Rotherham died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones complained that he didn't see the Article 50 letter before it was published, despite discussing it in general terms with the prime minister. He feels the devolved administrations have been treated with a lack of respect. Alun Cairns stated that the UK government needs to act in the interests of the whole of the UK. Mrs. May mentioned in the letter that they will consult on which powers should reside in Westminster and which should be devolved, with the expectation of a significant increase in the decision-making power of each devolved administration. The specific powers are unknown, and Carwyn Jones fears there won't be any money to accompany the powers after 2020.

Two cars were damaged in Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin said he was "appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community". Police were "carrying out duties" when attacked. Police appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was ousted due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The board does not expect him to return. Mr. Charney's lawyer claims the statements made were false and an invasion of privacy. The court filing documents evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts. The company says Mr. Charney violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. The board believes it would be hard to find any company willing to hire Mr. Charney. American Apparel was granted a restraining order preventing him from making negative statements about the company.

The game will be available on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The two teams previously played in Patras, Greece, with Greece winning 92-64. Three members of the Greek team will be missing for this game. This is Britain's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017. After this game, the team will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland. The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website from 17:30-19:30.

A producer requested a piece to camera on the new Apple iPhone, which was not yet available. The author remembered they had been offered an interview with Apple’s marketing chief Phil Schiller. The author asked to see the iPhone before the interview and brandished it at the camera for a news piece. The author defended the coverage, stating that some products merit coverage because they promise a step change in the way we lived. The author notes that the smartphone has been the key transformative technology of the last decade. The iPhone radically changed the way we thought about photography and other activities. The author states that the genius of Steve Jobs was to realize that without an attractive user interface many people wouldn’t do more with their phones than talk and text.

Cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire have ingested a toxic substance. Seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday. Three other cats in the area have died in the last seven days, while another cat died two weeks ago. Meereen's owner said the cat came home on Friday evening and was shivering. The cat was found behind the sofa, foaming from the mouth and trying to be sick. It was confirmed she had consumed antifreeze and died three days later. An RSPCA inspector is appealing for everyone in the area to ensure pesticides and chemicals were stored safely.

The Syriza government is poised to agree and implement more austerity and liberalization measures. Greece's resorts are full, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year. Greeks are not protesting the already-announced VAT increases and pension cuts. Alexis Tsipras is rushing to agree to terms he previously rejected to obtain €86bn of new credit. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity. Greece is suffering from a vicious economic squeeze. The new bailout will only hold if Tsipras can offer hope of better times ahead.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell, will return to EastEnders for a brief time for Barbara's final episodes. Barbara's character, Peggy, returned to tell her son Phil that her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in the spring. Kemp played Grant from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006. Grant will return to bring the Mitchell family back together.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles. Her parents knew Dhillon was responsible when police informed them of her death. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Alice's parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of the dangers of stalking.

EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point project, but the UK government launched a further review of the project. Critics have warned of environmental damage, escalating costs, and that the plant is being built by foreign governments. One third of the £18bn cost is being provided by Chinese investors. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement. The project has been hit by concerns about EDF's financial capacity.

A new divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with, though there is no obligation to name them. Family lawyers are concerned that naming a third party increases conflict and complexity. The form was updated to be more user-friendly, but the guidance that it is not normally necessary to name the third party is in smaller print. Naming the third party makes them part of the court case. In 2015, there were just over 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales, with adultery being the reason for 12,148 of them.

Ministers are placing too much emphasis on the environment at the expense of trees grown for timber. Britain is the world's third largest importer of wood. At least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be re-planted. The forestry industry is estimated to be worth more than £450m a year to the Welsh economy. There is a conflict with environmental policy as ministers want more native, broadleaf species of trees. The Welsh government wants a balance between the environmental, the economic and the social in how forestry is developed. 90 hectares were planted last year but there needed to be 20,000 hectares a year to meet long-term targets.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge. Emergency crews were called to Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at about 16:40. The boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital, in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to men of the Arctic Convoys. The convoys consisted of vessels which traveled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II. The Russian embassy said the convoys allowed Russian soldiers to defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The Foreign Office initially did not allow Russia to honor the veterans as it broke the rules on foreign medals. The British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012. The Foreign Office allowed an "exception to the rules" last year and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London on 16 June 2013.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in offenders starting work and too many were let off for not attending. In one case, an offender completed only 16 hours in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's 15 recommendations. Unpaid work, or "community payback," can be 40 to 300 hours for offenses like shoplifting, theft, drug offenses, or criminal damage. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work. Inspectors looked at 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders. The report found that the organization of unpaid work was difficult, and that it was often viewed as simply a punishment. The chief inspector of probation called for "urgent remedial action". The Ministry of Justice said it wanted "much more effective rehabilitation" and was taking action to implement the recommendations.

A comedian was called a "hypocrite" for campaigning for economic and political "revolution" while living in a luxury home. He was asked about his own accommodation by a TV reporter and called the journalist "a snide" before walking off. The comedian has been accused of hypocrisy before and has stated that he knows he has to change and that part of that will be sharing wealth. He also stated that he has done a lot of daft things while under the capitalist system. He believes that people don't want inequality on the agenda because it is a real problem that needs to be addressed.

Dr. Venter turned mapping the human genome into a race, which was not well received by the scientific community. He is known for his lack of modesty and wealth. He sped up the process of human genomics and then worked on creating a synthetic life form called Synthia. He was not a good student as a boy, but after serving in Vietnam, he became determined to be a doctor. He excelled in research and realized the importance of decoding genes. He used an automated decoding machine to speed up the process and switched his focus to messenger molecules. He left the NIH to start a private research institute and unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism. He formed Celera Genomics to crack the human genetic code, which was completed in 2001. He formed the J Craig Venter Institute to create the world's first synthetic life form. He also collected life forms from the ocean to sequence their genomes.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England found that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of parents said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were among the least popular. 628 of the parents questioned had children who ate school lunches. About four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools. More children in Scotland eat school lunches - about 46%.

Morata, 23, plays for Spain at Euro 2016. He joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real. Real has an option to buy him back for up to 30m euros. Morata has scored three times for Spain in France and 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in back-to-back Champions League finals. He came through the ranks at Real, making his first team debut at 18, and scored 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Wilson rejoined Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, but has been without a team since being released in May. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground. He has also previously had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is disposing of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business around £80m. Fresh & Easy has lost money since opening in 2007. It will cost Tesco £150m to dispose of the brand. Yucaipa, a private equity company, is taking over the business. Tesco has the option to buy a stake if the business becomes profitable.
He experienced racial abuse, overcame it, and after considering representing France, is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. There is also a guide on how to get into martial arts.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields in the European range covered 375 sq km, which fell to 275 sq km by the late 2000s. The research was presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting. The new French Alps glaciers inventory was produced by Marie Gardent and colleagues. The team used map archives, past satellite imagery and aerial photographs. The only existing glacial inventory from the French Alps was published four decades ago and found the overall area of ice to be about 375 sq km. By 1985-86, glacial coverage had decreased to 340 sq km. Since then, the area has been reduced to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s. The greatest losses have been seen in the southern sectors. The glacier retreat is less important in the northern Alps than in the southern Alps.

The Scottish national team has won all five of their qualifiers and will play Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. Both teams are undefeated, and the outcome of this game and the return fixture will likely decide who tops the group. The best six of the eight group runners-up also qualify automatically, so Scotland is in a good position to reach the finals. Many of the Scottish players play in leagues outside of Scotland, which they believe benefits the national team.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England following a complaint from a woman in south London, who alleged harassment over a two-year period. Mr. Campbell was released on bail and said the allegations concerned some tweets that were not threatening. He accused the media of "innuendo" designed to encourage "speculations". The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegation of online harassment. Mr. Campbell has been bailed until mid-September.

Peta wants the Jolly Fisherman mascot to be replaced with a fish with the slogan Skegness - A Happy Plaice. The mayor of Skegness said all suggestions were welcome but did not think there would be much support for Jolly to be axed. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 and has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. Peta said Jolly "evokes images of cruelty to animals" and their suggestion would give the resort an opportunity to rebrand itself. The mayor said the Jolly Fisherman was loved by adults and children alike and he doesn't feel Jolly has ever come across as portraying animal cruelty.

The visitors, Georgia, scored first with a try by Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland quickly took the lead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson extended the lead after halftime. Lobzhanidze scored a second try, but Hogg scored again. Scotland won the match, with a final score of 43-16.

Widnes led 14-6 at half-time with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van and Chris Bridge, while Paddy Flynn scored for Cas. Widnes extended their lead to 38-12 with tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor. Despite three Cas tries, Widnes held on to win. Widnes moved to seventh, while Castleford remained in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released from the US facility in Cuba after a review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. He is the first inmate to be freed since May. He now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait. His release brings down the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner and up to 400 people took part in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey. The national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung as the service ended. The first time Anzac Day was commemorated in the capital was in 1916. The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war.

Clarkson, 30, joined St Mirren in July and could make his debut against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season. He has been playing for the U20s to keep his match fitness up. Clarkson has made almost 400 senior appearances at club level and was capped twice for Scotland in 2008. St Mirren are eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of Alloa.

The turkey firm was sold to Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. There were fears the new owners would not take on the existing workers' pension scheme, but guarantees were given that all current agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004 and members have an alternative pension scheme which is unaffected by the takeover. The new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to a highly profitable business by greater investment, cost savings and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken and not just turkeys.

The council decided the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July due to problems with the new ferry. The council ordered a review of the project by auditors. The ferry has broken down, run aground, and been suspended due to training issues. Cars have been damaged getting on and off. Local businesses have suffered losses. Compensation for businesses is up for discussion. The council authorized ramp extensions to resolve vehicle scraping and groundings were resolved.

The UK fishing industry, which voted heavily to leave the EU, may be marginalized in Brexit negotiations despite the industry's desire to regain control over UK waters. The industry only produces a half of one percent of GDP and employs 12,000 fishers. The UK may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a deal to maintain market access. The report also suggests that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or permitting images to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014. He was made the subject of a community payback order and put on the sex offenders register. He has now been removed from his profession's register. Most of the images he had downloaded were of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses with no sexual activity. The panel found that Geaney had failed to uphold the standards expected of the profession and found him unfit to teach. He was prohibited from applying to re-register for a period of two years.

A fire at a site on Duncan Street on March 2nd caused travel delays and reduced train services. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The fire service raised concerns to the EA in February over the impact a fire could have. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, effective August 7th, and the company is required to remove all waste. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile of chemical weapons. A shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia. The Syrian government denies using barrel bombs and claims they are defending their people against terrorist attacks. The Syrian government also denies reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison. The US said that only about 4% of Syria's chemical weapons stockpile has left the country. Russia has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast by March 1. A deadline was set last year for all the weapons to be destroyed by the end of June.

England won against Pakistan at Old Trafford to level the series. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. Pakistan were bowled out for 198 and 234. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq said they are short of confidence.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is reviewing the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners and their families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will look at factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment. The chair of Care Forum Wales is disappointed that the commissioner has not included a provider expert on the main advisory panel.

Sheerin, 39, former Dons midfielder, has been player-manager at the Red Lichties since 2010 and replaces Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing season 2013-14 bottom of League One. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser said boss Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after "a comprehensive process". Sheerin guided the Arbroath to their first national trophy in their history by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Saturday's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea wants to quickly appoint a new boss, with Paul Clement as the first choice. Curtis believes Swansea has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014. He also believes the current squad is good enough to stay up.

Dr. Venter turned mapping the human genome into a competitive race, which was not well received by the scientific community. He is known for his lack of modesty and wealth. He sped up the process of human genomics. After publishing the human genome, he worked on creating a synthetic life form called Synthia. He was inspired to become a doctor and not waste time after serving in Vietnam. He excelled in research and realized the importance of decoding genes. He used an automated decoding machine to speed up the process. He switched his attention to messenger molecules to churn out gene sequences at unprecedented rates. He left the NIH and set up a private research institute. He unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism. He formed Celera Genomics to crack the entire human genetic code. He formed the J Craig Venter Institute to create the world's first synthetic life form. He has also collected life forms in the ocean to sequence genomes.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships are low quality and too short compared to other European countries. They suggest creating thousands of apprenticeships to boost the economy and improve job prospects. The report found that fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 apprenticeships starting in England each year are rated at level three, which is equivalent to A-level. Only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany. The report also notes that England's vocational system has 18,000 different qualifications, while Germany has 330. The report calls for apprenticeships to be radically expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, with the majority at level three for at least three years.

The Briton finished more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey can win a 17th title in Saturday's road race. The 37-year-old is targeting further Paralympic success at next year's Games in Rio de Janeiro. Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals. She has won 11 gold, eight silver and three bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. Storey began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Conference Premier due to financial issues, despite efforts to meet payment deadlines. Chester has been reinstated as a Conference Premier club, and Hayes & Yeading will remain in Conference South. Hereford's debt to football creditors was £148,000, and they also owe over £70,000 in taxes. The club was taken over by Tommy Agombar, but they failed to meet the extended deadlines.

The former Manchester City man, 30, won 61 caps for England after making his senior debut in 2009. He was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships but played just three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, picking up 46 caps after making his first appearance in 2004. He scored his first, and only, international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

He died at his home in Cambridge after an illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service at a later date. He was an influential figure in early music, founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directing it for 30 years. The AAM made over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University and held positions with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, the Early Music Consort of London, the King's Lynn Festival, and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He also taught at Harvard University, the University of Cambridge, and Cornell University.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping. His family requested a place for him at a special school but were told in September that all special schools in the area were full. The boy's mother says he misses being around people and feels isolated. The family has now been told that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school and the hope is that their son will be able to start there in the next few weeks. The Education Authority is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland.

The Welsh Rugby Union is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons and see Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. County has a lease to use the ground until 2023 and primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. County are two points clear of League Two relegation with two games remaining. Newport secured promotion back to the Football League in 2013, and relegation would be a "massive" blow.

Last weekend, the country was declared free of the virus that killed almost 4,000 people in the country over the past 18 months. A man was kidnapped at 15 by RUF rebels and forced to fight. He escaped and met a preacher who encouraged him to help rebuild the nation. During the Ebola crisis in 2014, he helped educate over 10,000 people, supported 11,000 people with food, and helped set up an Ebola treatment unit. The Ebola outbreak resulted in 3,955 deaths in Sierra Leone.

A collection of 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs faced being auctioned to pay off a pottery firm's pension debt. A public fundraising campaign hit its target in a month. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, before it is loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The Wedgwood Museum inherited Waterford Wedgwood plc's pension bill after the firm collapsed in 2009. In 2011 a high court judge ruled its collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund.

Dan Groves said the "finer points" of a deal which could see Wright buy 20% of the club are yet to be released. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright played non-league football for a succession of clubs. Billericay have recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool scored first with a goal from Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized with a goal from Kurtis Guthrie. Colchester's Sean Murray received a red card.

The disused Fawley power station chimney would be the tallest attraction south of London's Shard. It would be the centrepiece of a "merchant city" development. The power station closed in 2013 after more than 40 years in operation. The development includes a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. Building could start in 2018. The oil-fired Fawley Power Station was commissioned in 1971 and was capable of powering one million homes. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016. The 198 meter-high chimney dominates the Solent skyline.

Latham won a bronze medal in the Hong Kong championships, GB's second medal of the event. In the men's team pursuit, GB were beaten to the bronze medal by Italy. Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final. The GB women's team pursuit finished fifth in the heats. Katy Marchant was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell, will return to EastEnders for a brief time for Barbara's final episodes. Barbara's character, Peggy, returned to tell her son Phil that her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in the spring. Kemp played Grant from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006. Grant will return to bring the Mitchell family back together.

Sadio Mane scored twice as Spurs lost at Anfield. Pochettino said it is difficult to fight for the Premier League if they show a lack of desire to win. Spurs have won just twice on the road since 24 September. In their past 17 meetings with the other top-six sides away from home, Spurs have won just once. Danny Murphy said Spurs were all over the place and should have stuck with a back three.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP lost for the first time in key northern states and also lost control of Adamawa. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states. The elections were marred by violence in some areas. The APC retained power in Lagos state.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Visitors can use an app to trigger online information from signs and posters, including videos and band interviews. The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean are among this year's acts. The app will also allow people around the world to interact with the festival.

Park View and Nansen Primary academies, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools said parents tried to undermine her authority. Ofsted published 21 reports into schools allegedly targeted as part of a hardline Muslim takeover, with five of those schools, including Park View and Oldknow, rated inadequate. Lord Nash criticized the trust for failing to promote "spiritual, moral, social and cultural development of pupils". The report into Park View School said the academy's work to keep students safe, including from extremism, was inadequate. Parents at the schools have criticized Ofsted's reports and accused inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution told Ipswich Crown Court that eye specialist Honey Rose's conduct was so far below the expected standard it was "criminal". Ms. Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The alleged failure of Ms. Rose to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the routine test, and refer him on for further investigation, was "at the heart of the prosecution case". A build-up of fluid in his brain increased pressure in Vinnie's skull and ultimately led to his death. The prosecution alleges that Vinnie's death was preventable and would have been prevented had Ms. Rose done her job properly.

Clive Weatherhogg set up meetings between a woman and a man he found through an adult website, and filmed them having sex. He sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and found guilty of coercing the woman to engage in sexual activity and intercourse with the man. He was also convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner.

Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson hitting 56, Gary Wilson 41, and captain William Porterfield 39. Afghanistan reached 171-4 with Samiullah Shenwari scoring 56 and Mohammad Shahzad 47. Ireland's Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23. Ireland's captain said they fell short of a big score and didn't execute well with the ball. Boyd Rankin is out for the T20s due to a back problem but is expected to return for the ODIs.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost of Neymar to the club is £106.8m. Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president following accusations he misappropriated money. A judge ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona made a tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found dead on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK detectives worked with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21. The UK detectives will compile a report and update the families. The two suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery. Post-mortem examinations found Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Ms. Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police said DNA found on Ms. Witheridge matched samples taken from the suspects.

The Scottish national team has won all five of their qualifiers and will play Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. A victory would secure their place in the finals. The team has lost in the play-offs for Euro 2013 and last year's World Cup. Iceland is ranked one place above Scotland. The outcome of the game will likely decide who tops the group. The best six of the eight group runners-up also qualify automatically. 12 of the 20 players in the Scottish squad play outside of Scotland.

Third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. Apple has implemented a security measure that requires a four-digit code to be entered after a username and password on a new device. This code is sent via text or Apple's Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud is denied. A 14-character recovery key can be used to regain access if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple is being encouraged to make two-factor authentication the default option.

UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Tories spent £2,980,815, the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, and Labour spent £1,027,339. The figures cover the campaign period from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP's campaign spending was 68p per vote, Labour's was 26p per vote, the Conservatives' was 79p per vote and the Lib Dems' was £1.45 per vote. The Green Party spent £534,249 on its campaign, which was 43p per vote. The six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning. All but Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

Anderson, 27, a centre-back, has cancelled his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson. Nicholson said Anderson is a leader-type player and Keating is young and hungry. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, but had never collapsed before. He had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

Tricia Marwick was emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the parliament. Ms. Marwick, Mr. Salmond, and Mr. McNeil are among those standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on May 5th. Mr. Salmond believes Scotland is diverse, not divided, and that the parliament needs to assume greater responsibility. Mr. McNeil warned that Holyrood has things to learn from Westminster. Annabel Goldie is also leaving Holyrood.

The star will play Mrs Potts, Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and the film will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will play Gaston. Josh Gad will play LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will reveal its intentions at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. Ninety-six football fans were fatally injured in the 1989 stadium disaster. Last year, new inquests concluded the fans had been unlawfully killed. In January, files of evidence relating to 23 suspects were referred to the CPS to decide whether charges should be brought. Relatives have been invited to a private meeting in Warrington, where they will be informed of the decisions.

Chelmsford Prison has had "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over the wall. A former inmate said the jail was "notorious" for being "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A woman who lives near the prison said she had witnessed packages being thrown over the wall "four times in two weeks." The Ministry of Justice said staff worked "extremely hard" to stop contraband from getting into prisons and that laws had been introduced which mean people who smuggle packages over prison walls could be jailed for up to two years.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School. Brian Wright, 55, admitted to striking Mrs. Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care. Mr. Wright said he was blinded by the setting sun and his VW Golf failed to stop for a red light. Mrs. Blackburn was a lollipop lady for 20 years and was on duty when she was hit.

Muir will not be with the Scotland team at next year's event on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Her exams are in May, and the Commonwealths are in April. She is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March. She achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m.

Trevor Deely, 22, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search of a site in Chapelizod in Dublin started on Saturday morning. The search will involve excavations and is expected to take a number of weeks. CCTV footage shows Mr. Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. Detectives released the footage in April and appealed for the man to come forward. The man seen in the CCTV has not yet been identified.

Del Potro defeated a Swiss player in four sets, despite being ranked 165th after missing two years due to injury. He will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. Nick Kyrgios is also in the same half of the draw as Murray and will play Feliciano Lopez in the third round. Other players who won their matches include Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations for complaints against Caf, but apologized. Morocco was allowed to enter the 2017 qualifying draw after a ban was overturned. Morocco was previously punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns. Tunisia's complaints stemmed from a controversial penalty in their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was secured after a meeting with Caf.

McLaren, a team with a history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling. Their slump began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and now the problem lies with the Honda power-unit. Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, the team is aiming for a fourth or third row grid position. McLaren has had periods of success, including a dominant era with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and later with Mika Hakkinen. They were involved in scandals in 2007 and 2009. The team's history has been a cycle of triumph and decline, and Ron Dennis believes they will return to success.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 for a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar, with till receipts showing alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside of licensing hours. Ms. O'Neill was fined £3,000 and Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points as the Golden State Warriors beat the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105. Curry hit eight 3-pointers, eclipsing his previous record of 272. Klay Thompson scored 26 points. The Chicago Bulls beat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol scoring 16 points and 15 rebounds.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen visited Liverpool's Melwood training ground, where he was introduced to players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic as a competition winner. Van Velzen then showcased his free-kick skills, impressing the players. Balotelli also took some free-kicks. Van Velzen revealed he was pretending to not be good at free-kicks and enjoyed seeing the players' reactions. He also surprised Balotelli by unveiling his infamous slogan.

Women with the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed. A study found that oophorectomy reduced breast cancer deaths by 62% in women with the BRCA1 mutation, and reduced death from all causes by 65%. The protective effect was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. Oophorectomy was particularly effective for survival in women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina on Easter Sunday. The train was headed from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured. The train was delayed for almost three hours before continuing on its way. The couple may have lived in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked for the DEA as an undercover operative for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. He was a former member of the Medellin cartel. He helped take down Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. He was not paid for his work, but was promised citizenship. The DEA refused to help him with citizenship after he retired due to declining health. He is now facing deportation and fears for his life if he is sent back to Colombia.

The US body that regulates internet addresses is looking into whether a Canadian company is illegally using the new '.sucks' domain name to extract large sums from celebrities and companies. Kevin Spacey is among celebrities who have paid to have their names removed from the domains. Companies such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have also been targeted. The owners of the '.sucks' domains are recommended to resell them for around $2,499 a year.

A baby boy's body was found in a pond in 1988. 27 years later, the mother was identified through DNA. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she explained the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy. The baby was reburied and named Peter. Police ruled out foul play and the mother remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver was ordered to pay compensation to a passenger who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving car. The driver mistakenly thought the passenger was going to avoid paying the fare and drove him in the opposite direction. The passenger jumped out of the car while it was traveling at more than 20mph. The judge ruled the driver had unlawfully imprisoned the passenger and was therefore entitled to damages. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided but is set to be around 50 per cent of what the family had requested.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas on Wednesday night due to several storms. A tornado was reported 6 miles northwest of Goddard, and other reports came from southwestern Kansas. A tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, with reports of wind damage and flooding. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is fighting Lyoto Machida in a middleweight match. Rockhold is seeking his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. He plans to be the "bull" and dominate Machida, who he sees as the "matador". Machida is also confident and believes he can win and earn a title shot. Both fighters respect each other.

A light general aviation aircraft touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear and skidded along the runway on its belly in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane's propellers hit the ground, but the pilot re-engaged the engines and took off. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manuel Pellegrini is disappointed in Yaya Toure's performance this season but will back him until the end of the season. Manchester City will listen to offers for Toure in the summer. Joe Hart said the players have let the manager down. Manchester City want to sign West Ham left back Aaron Cresswell in the summer. Sam Allardyce warned Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to City.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive, will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence from an Italian court expired. Rancadore was convicted in absentia in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. Although his conviction remains, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still have to be heard by the Italian supreme court.

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The other co-favorites are Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. Mr. Mole will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. McCoy announced his intention to quit riding after riding Mr. Mole to victory at Newbury in February. Other runners include Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Ritter recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body, which she had previously declined to see. Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder six years ago and sentenced to 44 years. Marcia's body was found 150 yards from her home. Barrett was arrested in 2006 after his DNA matched that on Marcia's clothing.

Rory McIlroy believes he will win the Masters to complete the career grand slam. His final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011 was the most important day of his career. He is looking to become the sixth player to win all four major titles. McIlroy has one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances. He feels it is a course he can do very well at and win multiple times. McIlroy's success last year came despite calling off his wedding and a legal dispute. He hopes the golf course can be his sanctuary from the pressure surrounding Augusta.

This week, four rainbows appeared in the New York sky, a fashion CEO snapped a photo, exotic dancers are hired for wakes in rural China, RDJ was agitated by a UK interviewer, lip plumping is a new trend, a 102-year-old went back in time with filmmakers, a prom-posal referenced bombs, Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast, Johnny Depp is unrecognizable in the Black Mass trailer, a pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombed his son.

In the past 12 months, 272 children in England were hospitalized with disabilities caused by fetal alcohol syndrome. The World Health Organization suggests that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure. One example is 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who has fetal alcohol syndrome and requires assistance with daily tasks. The government advises pregnant women not to drink alcohol, but some believe the guidance should be changed to advise no alcohol consumption during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old, attempted to rob a store with an axe. The shopkeeper tackled him, and the shopkeeper's wife hit McKerry with a baseball bat. McKerry was arrested and jailed for six years. McKerry was nicknamed "boomerang boy" or "homing pigeon boy" due to his history of returning home after committing crimes.
