Four Royal Navy sailors are charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party in Nova Scotia. They must stay in Nova Scotia until their trial. They were given bail with conditions including surrendering their passports, living at a naval base, and remaining employed by the navy. The alleged assault occurred after a hockey game. The four men are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault.

RJ Jackson, a four-year-old, has Netherton's syndrome, a rare disease causing his skin to appear red and scaly. His mother, Valerie Jackson, was reported to the police for child abuse after a stranger mistook his condition for scalding. She regularly applies creams to his skin, but they still face taunts and discrimination due to his appearance. Netherton's syndrome is a genetic condition with no cure, but symptoms can improve over time.

Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" adverts featuring a bikini-clad model were removed from the London Underground after a three-week advertising period. The adverts caused controversy, with over 50,000 signatures on a petition to remove them, and over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority. Critics felt the adverts promoted an unhealthy body image. Protein World defended the campaign, while also receiving threats, including a bomb threat. The Advertising Standards Authority is assessing the complaints.

Rail firms are planning fare hikes of up to 87% despite party leaders pledging to freeze prices. The Prime Minister has requested First Great Western (FGW) review its decision to almost double some fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds. Passengers traveling from Charlbury will be forced to pay £62.40 instead of £33.30 for a return ticket. Train companies have three windows every year to increase unregulated fares. Other price hikes include an off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton and an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool. Virgin has said the majority of its price hikes affected Virgin trains-only fares.

John Young, 66, a former soldier, was blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown through his front door when he confronted thugs who were throwing stones at his property in Oldham. The attack occurred three weeks after his wedding to Elaine, 54. Police are investigating, but there appears to be no motive. The couple are now moving due to feeling unsafe.

Tom Poynton, a Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension after returning from leg injuries sustained in a road accident in which his father died. He missed the entire 2014 season and had an ankle operation, but made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. He will be available for the start of the season and is now committed to the county until the end of the 2016 season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. He used a ninja turtle mask to help him feel stronger during radiotherapy. He was told he is cancer-free after battling the disease for a year. Harley's story became famous and he received gifts from Nickelodeon. He underwent chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, and a stem cell transplant. He also had weeks of radiotherapy. Neuroblastoma is a rare and aggressive childhood cancer that affects fewer than 100 children in the UK each year.

Tim Sherwood believes Jack Grealish should focus on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future. Grealish is wanted by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood wants Grealish to focus on playing for Aston Villa. Grealish's dad also agrees that his son should focus on his club football first. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season.

Private jet landing fees can vary dramatically, with some surprising hubs having the highest fees. The most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda Airport being the most expensive at £4,559. The private jet industry is worth $16.7 trillion in the US and $15.8 trillion in Europe. Busiest times for private jets are during sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix.

Katie Gallegos took her dogs, Cooper and Daisy, to McDonald's for ice cream. While Daisy took a few licks, Cooper ate the rest of the cone in one bite. Cooper always eats very quickly, so Daisy gets her fill first. The video of Cooper's ice cream outing has been watched more than seven million times. Some viewers criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream, but she insists it's fine. The dogs also visit Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," which Cooper also quickly consumes.

Gary Locke has been given the role of manager at Kilmarnock on a permanent basis after signing a three-year deal. He joined the club as assistant boss last summer, and took control of the team in February. He has lost just once in seven games since taking over.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, says her son's school threatened to suspend him for wearing essential oils to help with his autism. The school said the oils, made by Doterra, smelled and were a distraction. Kemp applies the oils to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. The school sent a letter saying the oils created a problem for staff and students. The school district later said they would not suspend him, calling it a health issue. The family uses oils with scents such as lavender, chamomile and sandalwood.

A fire obliterated a 90-condo beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach on Wednesday at 3 pm. The fire was so intense it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire teams were deployed but could not get inside the building. The building is called the Sandpiper complex and is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November. The cause of the fire is being investigated, with claims it started near a car parked by the complex.

The Queen, age 88, was seen riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She does not wear a helmet, preferring a silk scarf. She has ridden since the age of four, when she was given a Shetland pony named Peggy. She has cut back on riding due to a knee injury. The Queen breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court. Fell ponies are an old breed, used throughout history for various purposes, and are now popular riding horses.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels resulted in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, who was allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama. The incident occurred after Yeaman was reportedly making a lot of noise at around 9 pm. Pama, who was sleeping at the time due to his 3 am shift, confronted Yeaman, and the situation escalated. Pama was granted conditional bail and is due back in court on May 18.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's football manager, talks to God daily but never about football and does not discuss the game with his wife. He and his family have worked with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger. Mourinho tries to separate his professional and family life. He prays daily but only goes to church regularly in Portugal. He only prays for things in his personal life, never about football. Mourinho was fined £25,000 for claiming there was a 'campaign' against Chelsea.

Bob Barker, who hosted "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to host the show for the first time in eight years on April 1. He handled the first game, "Lucky Seven," before turning hosting duties over to Drew Carey.

An off-duty secret service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 am on Friday for allegedly attempting to break into a house. He was charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. His security clearance was revoked and he was put on leave. Baldwin's arrest comes two days after a supervisor was put on leave for misconduct. The Homeland Security Department's inspector general is investigating both the supervisor's misconduct and a March 4 incident involving two officials driving into a secure area at the White House after drinking.

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away. He got out of his car and crept up to within 10 feet of the lion, armed only with a camera. The clicking sound of the camera alerted the lion, who jumped towards him, and he scrambled back into his car.

The New York City Police have released an image of a tattoo found on a woman who died in Brooklyn in hopes of identifying her. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 and was pronounced dead that evening. The woman had a heart tattoo with the name ‘Monique’ on her right leg. Police are still awaiting a medical examiner's report to find out the cause of death.

A New Zealand couple built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK because they could not afford to buy property. The project took a year and a half and cost about $25,000. The home is mostly self-sufficient with solar panels for power, a wood-fired stove, and water from a nearby spring.

Researchers claim that children who share iPads in class do much better in early literacy tests than those who do not. Courtney Blackwell found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in classes scored around 30 points higher than students who used the device on their own and non-ipad users. The findings suggest it's the collaborative learning around the technology that made the difference.

A piglet with no back legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed 'super pig', belongs to farmer, Ms. Duan, from Qionglai City in Sichuan Province, China. Villagers have flocked to see the piglet, and it is not the first two-legged animal to gain attention in China.

Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by the car of Francesco Dracone, who had come in for tires and fuel on lap 25. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center for treatment and received stitches for a cut on his leg and has been released. Dracone did not finish the race and wound up 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, was captured on CCTV smashing his dancer wife's head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face 5 times. He confessed to the murder, stating he was jealous of men looking at her. The victim, Cicera Alves de Sena, belonged to a dance troop called Jaula das Gostozuedas. Severiano was arrested after crashing a stolen car and police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in the car.

Sarah Wilson, author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed she almost took her own life due to anxiety. She felt isolated and couldn't see a way out. Her anxiety was linked to stress, thyroid disease, and distant family. She believes depression and anxiety are linked and that anxiety is becoming the "new depression." One in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after hitting her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. The charges were dropped because prosecutors deemed her actions justified after finding the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom. Oregon law allows for physical force against an intruder who won't leave a residence. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing Curtin and trying to get her boyfriend back into addiction. Curtin has since moved on from the relationship.

Gemma, a pit bull, was filmed at home in California being fed treats. Her owner tried to trick her by throwing a broccoli spear into the mix. Gemma showed disgust and spit the broccoli out. Other videos show Gemma enjoys sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The porn site took over the address after the young entrepreneur awards were scrapped in 2011 and the organizers allowed its registration on hsbc.com.hk to retire. HSBC removed the hyperlink and apologized to the public, stating they are not associated with the external site.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy called 911 after a fire broke out in his home on Sunday morning. He and his 9-year-old sister were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. The boy gave the dispatcher directions and stayed calm during the 11-minute call. Firefighters rescued the siblings by breaking a window. The siblings were taken to children's hospital with non-life threatening injuries. Three other family members were taken to medstar hospital after escaping on their own.

Blue fluorescent algae lit up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a 'beautiful supernatural scene' caused by millions of plankton omitting light. A similar display was shown in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. The glow is caused by noctiluca scintillans, a single celled phytoplankton that blossoms in the spring and the autumn.

New tests can identify genetic markers in tumors to determine aggressiveness, potentially sparing breast cancer patients from chemotherapy. These tests can tell women within days if they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. For some women, the risk is as low as five percent, which is comparable to the odds with chemotherapy. The newest test, endopredict, allows patients with a low score to opt out of chemotherapy. While most tests are currently private and cost around £2,500, there is hope they will become available on the NHS.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy. One ship, HMS Ocean, had five pregnant sailors removed in emergency evacuations in the last nine years. At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious. Eighteen other ships had emergency evacuations. There is a strict 'no touching' rule at sea. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990. Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after finding out they were pregnant. A further 102 women were evacuated from Iraq. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was found on the roof of the Japanese prime minister's residence. The drone was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing traces of cesium. The discovery is raising concerns about terrorism, especially regarding the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports, but not in most of Tokyo. The prime minister was not in his office at the time.

A security guard from China takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him on his motorbike every day because he is scared she will get lost if left alone. He ties a sash around both of their waists to make sure she doesn't fall off. His mother has her own room at his work, a bank, and he checks on her to make sure she has not wandered off.

A study found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, largely due to rising rates among women. In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers. The increases are driven largely by women's drinking habits as social norms change. About 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol in 2010.

UN officials warn that doctors are putting the health of women and their babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily. The procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary because it can lead to infections and even death. Just over a quarter of women giving birth in England now have a caesarean, and the rate has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The WHO said that this figure should ideally be between just 10% and 15%. A planned caesarean costs the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to a natural birth at £1,665. Previous research has found that as many as one in ten caesareans cause infections.

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested for breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after she broke into a home on Martha's Vineyard, lived there for at least a week, and sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. The owner, Mark Conklin, discovered her on April 17. Filkins claimed she owned the house, then fled. Police discovered a broken window. Filkins was arrested after attempting to get back into the home. Items missing include deck chairs, a grill, side tables, lamps, posters, pots, pans, linens, and a painting. Police are asking for the return of the items.

Bella Crooke lost her iPhone at a friend's birthday party. The phone was handed in to Albury police station. Police officers posted selfies and photos of the phone on Bella's Facebook page in an attempt to track her down. Bella eventually collected her phone from the police station.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was thrown into the air and mauled to death after getting caught in a fight between two adult male hippos. The calf's mother watched as it was flung into the air and dragged along the water. The calf died hours later from its injuries. A tour operator witnessed the event. The mother had tried to protect the calf from other hippos, but one of the adults grabbed the calf.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London is on the market for £575,000, which is a fraction of the price of neighboring homes. However, the lease has only three years remaining. The cost would work out to £191,000 per year, or £15,000 per month. If the buyer extends the lease, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The property is described as bright and well-proportioned with 1,990 sq/ft of space. It is one of two maisonettes being sold with three years remaining on the lease. The current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust, and a 90-year lease extension is likely to cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage that affected 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing baristas to give away free drinks. The outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. The issue has been resolved and stores are expected to open for business as usual. Some stores closed early to avoid giving away free products.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of west Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, which are being used to radicalize Muslims. These individuals participate in ordinary activities but have ulterior motives. Islamic extremist activity in Wales dates back to 1998. The area's rugged terrain is similar to that used by the British military for training. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting in North Wales. In 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested for plotting terror attacks. One of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead.

An Omura's whale, a species thought to be extinct, was found on a remote beach in Western Australia. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The 5.68m juvenile female was identified through DNA profiling. The find is significant because very little is known about the species, which was only described in scientific journals in 2003. The species is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body shape and several unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation.

A businesswoman believes Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president due to her hormones causing irrational decisions. The article argues that male hormones have historically impaired leaders' decisions and that women take fewer risks. It also highlights the bias against women in the workplace, noting that it is a significant barrier to women's success. The article concludes that equality benefits everyone and that gender bias needs to be addressed.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is selling his collection of over 200 antiques in a £100,000 auction due to downsizing. The collection includes a diorama of the battle of Agincourt, a portrait of Hardy holding a longbow, furniture, swords, rifles, silverware, and books. Hardy is a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, and was taught by Tolkien and C.S. Lewis. He is known for his roles in All Creatures Great and Small, playing Winston Churchill, and in the Harry Potter films.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky. He was on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. His mother was found dead at their home after a family member called for a well-being check. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day. He was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations council, who bypassed the usual bidding process. Eugene failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha. The 2007 World Championships held in Osaka, Japan was also awarded without a bidding process. Mo Farah won gold in the men's 10000 metres during the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Leonie Granger, an aspiring model, was jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after setting a honey trap for professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger befriended Hassan, who showered her with gifts, before allowing her boyfriend and an accomplice into his flat where they tied him up, kicked him to death, and ransacked his home for his winnings. Granger's co-defendants were jailed for life for murder.

Cesc Fabregas' form has declined after a strong start to the season, with his performances dipping since mid-January. His former club, Barcelona, noted a trend of his contributions decreasing as each season progressed. Despite this, he has 16 assists this season and Chelsea could need as many as six wins from their remaining nine games to win the Premier League title.

West Ham are discussing a deal for Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford after he impressed on trial. The 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United has offers from clubs in Belgium. West Ham have revealed season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289.

Police have dropped an investigation into an assault on huntsman Mike Lane, despite evidence provided. Lane was attacked by protesters with iron bars, suffering injuries including concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. The police have stopped the investigation due to insufficient evidence, but may reopen it if further evidence comes to light.

Adam Gadahn, known as the American mouthpiece of al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. He was not specifically targeted. Gadahn was a prominent member of al Qaeda, serving as its chief English-language propagandist. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda. He appeared in numerous videos threatening attacks and urging Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests. He also criticized U.S. presidents and called for lone-wolf attacks in the U.S. Gadahn had a prominent role in al Qaeda, including making recommendations for their media strategy.

Chinese parents are passionate about raising child prodigies. A viral video shows a five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo displaying impressive basketball skills. He has been playing since he was two and a half years old. His skills have gained him many fans in China. Netizens have left thousands of comments, some expressing disbelief and others feeling ashamed of their own skills.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the paedophile information exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s. O'Carroll attended a Hacked Off rally to lobby for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation and wants a statutory body to regulate the press. O'Carroll's involvement is an embarrassment to Hacked Off. PIE was formed in 1974 and also wanted incest to be legalized. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for `corrupting public morals'.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to create a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The empty pool was used for the ten pieces presentation. Ten pieces produces a capsule collection of ten pieces of unisex clothing designed to be worn in 20 ways. The show took place on a warm day with a blue sky.

Amir Khan, a boxer, spent a day at a safari park in northern California with his wife and daughter. He posed with and fed a white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. Khan also announced he will fight Chris Algieri on May 30.

A Palestinian teenager's name, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was added to an Israeli memorial for fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. His family objected to his inclusion, as did an organization called Almagor, who stated he was not a terror victim. The National Insurance Institute of Israel will remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial.

A young boy is filmed chasing the family cat around the garden in an attempt to use the cat as a pillow. The cat gets up and moves each time the boy lays on him. The cat eventually wanders off indoors. A later video shows the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his coaching job at a private academy after testifying about his past selling marijuana. Kushner testified that some of the officers on trial had stolen cash and marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. He had passed a background check when hired in 2010, and the 2007 charges were expunged. He was arrested again in 2011 and also pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Lawyers for the accused officers say the government case is based on lying drug dealers.

An explosion at a chemical plant in China's Fujian province injured six people. The plant produces paraxylene (px), a carcinogenic chemical. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak. Five of the six people were injured by broken glass. Over 600 firefighters were sent to battle the blaze. Residents near the plant heard the explosion and posted photos of the fire. The plant was hit by another explosion in 2013. The construction of px plants has sparked protests in several cities. The Zhangzhou plant was originally slated for Xiamen but was relocated due to pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish will continue to wear his socks low due to superstition, despite referees telling him to pull them up. He wears children's shinpads and does not plan to change. He made his first premier league start for Aston Villa against QPR.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage" and is unresponsive. She is no longer in a medically induced coma, but does not respond to visitors or familiar voices. She has a tracheostomy in her throat. Her father, Bobby Brown, said she was awake, but an attorney for the family said her condition has improved but the quality of her life will not be known for years. She has made it out of ICU and started a rehabilitation.

Russia is leading 2-0 in the Fed Cup after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova beat Sabine Lisicki and Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges. Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point in the second set. Russia needs one more win to reach the final.

Residents of New South Wales are warned to prepare for more floods and damage, with another storm predicted to hit later this week. An east coast low, similar to the one that caused damage last week, could bring heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday. The State Emergency Service is still working to complete over 4,000 jobs from last week's storm and is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts. The Hunter region is of particular concern. The heaviest rain is expected in the far northern parts of the state.

Nina Moric, a model, was treated in the hospital after collapsing due to low blood pressure, not from a suicide attempt as reported by Italian media. She posted photos of her injuries on Instagram and stated she was recovering at home. Her boyfriend suggested she had tried to commit suicide, but she denied this. Italian media also claimed she had tried to take her own life in 2009. She was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

The British public hopes Kate and William will choose a traditional name for their second child. A poll revealed that Diana is the favorite name for a girl, followed by Alice and Charlotte. If the child is a boy, James is the favorite name. A quarter of those polled hope for a girl. The majority of Brits support William taking six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near protesters in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 and wounding dozens. An Afghan lawmaker was among the 64 wounded. The Taliban denied responsibility and no other organization has claimed responsibility. The protesters were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The attack happened around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves has been with Barcelona for seven years, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. The player's agent said that negotiations are over after Alves rejected a three-year contract extension that was dependent on him playing in 60% of matches.

Pablo Osvaldo has urged Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. Osvaldo believes the duo would be a good fit for Boca and the fans would love to have them. Osvaldo has played with many great players but if he had to pick two, it would be Pirlo and Totti. Pirlo is one of the best midfielders in world football and Totti is a Roma legend.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, had a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse at Wincanton. He was back riding out the next day with just a cut on his nose. The fall has been watched hundreds of thousands of times online. Ferguson said he was lucky and that he got some abuse from the lads and picked up a few hundred twitter followers.

James Haskell posted an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man to celebrate the release of the new Avengers movie. Haskell is the captain of the London Wasps and returned to the club in 2012 after playing for other teams in France, Japan, and New Zealand. He first joined the Wasps in 2002 and has earned 57 caps for the England squad.

The wide leg trouser is a key trend for ss15, offering an alternative to skinny jeans. It can be styled with high heels to elongate the leg, and a simple top to keep the outfit in proportion. Denim is an easy way to achieve the trend, with Gucci and Topshop offering options. Other designers like Celine and Stella McCartney have showcased dressier styles.

The University of Michigan will proceed with a screening of "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. Over 200 students signed a petition asking the school not to show the movie, but a counter-petition asked school officials to reconsider. The university's vice president for student life said it was a mistake to cancel the showing and that the show will go on. Umix will also offer a screening of "Paddington" for those who would rather not attend "American Sniper."

Two French tourists allegedly ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a flame to make contact with a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth in Western Australia on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed. The two men, aged 18 and 24, were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty. They will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas can be found on some small islands off the West Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old dancer from the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen any motion pictures of herself dancing. Mark Cantor and volunteers put together a video of "soundies" and showed them to Barker at her nursing home, which delighted her.

A study shows that washing your own car is becoming less common in Britain. A third of men and three-quarters of women have never washed their own car. Only 12% of men wash their car regularly. 5% of people have asked their children to wash the car for pocket money. Reasons for the decline include shops being open on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and larger vehicles. Brits are more likely to wash their own car during the holidays. Cars are most likely to be washed by their owners every week in Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield and least likely in Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh. Audis, Toyotas and BMWs are most likely to be washed by their owners and Range Rovers, Peugeots and Mercedes least often.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact since 2008, but believes Liverpool can overcome his departure. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, and could end his Liverpool career in the final on his birthday before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel says Gerrard is still one of the best players in the world and helped him settle at Liverpool. Skrtel believes Liverpool has potential replacements for Gerrard. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the Liverpool line-up for the match against Villa.

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one on the fourth hole of the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This was his first ace on the course. Five hole-in-ones were made that day, tying the record from 2002. Camilo Villegas also had two hole-in-ones but lost in a play-off to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus was the youngest person to wear a green jacket in 1963 and won his sixth in 1986. He is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas on Wednesday night as several storms brought reports of twisters. Spotters reported a tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard. Other reports of tornadoes came in from southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. A tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, where there were reports of wind damage and flooding. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, claiming he meant to use a taser. The judge allowed Bates to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, which upset Harris's family. Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. Bates was involved in the arrest of Harris during a weapons sting operation. Bates claims the shooting was accidental and has apologized to the Harris family. The lawyer for Harris's family claims Bates was not qualified to be on the force. Some supervisors were told to forge Bates' records and were reassigned when they refused. Bates's lawyer released training documents that they say prove Bates had proper training. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. McGregor has a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, and already has a gorilla tattoo on his chest. McGregor claims he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it. The pair had a promotional tour in Dublin where McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott was criticized by anti-drinking campaigners for skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, with critics claiming he was glorifying binge drinking and associating being a man with drinking. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, said it was problematic that the prime minister was showcasing his masculinity by skolling a beer. The prime minister took about six seconds to down the schooner as players cheered. Health minister Sussan Ley defended Mr. Abbott's actions. Mr. Abbott also gave a speech to the players.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County, linked to intravenous drug use, primarily the painkiller Opana. This outbreak prompted a temporary needle exchange program, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, with 1,400 used syringes returned. The program's future and legislation for similar programs in other counties are uncertain, as there are concerns about needle exchanges promoting drug use. The federal government bans public funding of needle exchange programs.

An Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a test about his favorite football club. She scored 43.5 out of 50, or 87%, and he said he wouldn't dump her. Saskia posted the test to Twitter. The test included multiple choice, tables, and "in your own words" sections. She struggled with player positions and naming all 11 starting players. She got creative with some answers, and her boyfriend marked wrong answers with an angry face. Some people on Twitter thought the boyfriend was a legend, while others thought he took things too far.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked for the DEA as an undercover operative for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. He was a mid-level member of the Medellin cartel in the 1980s. He provided information about his former bosses and associates and helped carry out undercover stings around the world. He was not paid for his work, but was promised US citizenship, which he has not received. He is now facing deportation and fears for his life if he is sent back to Colombia.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being raped by five men from her village. Her family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack. She is now in the hospital with 70% burns. The accused men have been arrested. There is heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India after a documentary about the gang rape and murder of an Indian student was banned. Recent attacks in India have resulted in street protests.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is dreaming of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday's derby but will have to do so without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, who are not fit enough to play. Van Gaal wants his side to win to move up the table and potentially finish in the top three. He acknowledges that City will be a challenge and is not motivated by revenge for their previous loss.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest was in response to the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Tickets for the game started at £64. Fans displayed banners inside and outside the stadium, and further protests are expected.

A newborn baby, Star, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition. After an unsuccessful operation to unblock her bile ducts, she needed a liver transplant. Her mother's twin sister, Shanell, donated part of her liver, saving Star's life. Star has since recovered well, but will need lifelong medication.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, which involved shooting balls into the boot of a car and over a car used as a net. Remy and Willian won the final round, which involved shooting at cars from long range, but Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror off one of the cars.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. Dellinger initially told investigators he was trying to kill himself, but during his sentencing, he stated he was not suicidal. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. His attorneys claimed he was suffering from ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, prozac, and multiple sclerosis.

Lacey Spears was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for poisoning her five-year-old son with salt. The boy's father expressed his hope that she would die in prison and that she would be beaten to death. Prosecutors said Spears made her son ill because she had a bizarre need for attention. Spears' lawyer said she was innocent and blamed the hospital for negligence.

Two new strains of influenza, H3N2 and B/Phuket, caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the US. An improved vaccine, which includes protection against these strains, is arriving in Australia a month later than expected. High-risk groups will be able to access free flu shots from April 20. Experts recommend everyone get the vaccine, which also protects against H1N1. The modified vaccine is expected to be a good match for the circulating strains.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are defending it against a critique in National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts. The tomb is described as having "all the historical character of an office lobby" by the magazine. The state of Illinois faces a financial crisis and the governor has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb. The tomb has undergone recent repairs and renovations, but has had reduced hours and staffing due to previous budget cuts. The tomb was designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated in 1874.

Nineties fashion trends like chokers and logo t-shirts are popular, but the return of JNCO jeans is not welcomed by everyone. Other trends from the nineties and noughties that are making a comeback include bucket hats, camouflage print, taking trends to the max, Ugg boots, daisy dukes, juicy couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers.

This week, four rainbows appeared in the New York sky, a fashion CEO snapped a photo, China is cracking down on exotic dancers at wakes, RDJ was agitated by a UK interviewer, lip plumping is a new trend, a 102-year-old went back in time with filmmakers, a prom-posal referencing bombs was rejected, Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', Johnny Depp is unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer, a pregnancy announcement referenced 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad photobombed his son.

Serena Williams received a giant cake after her 700th career victory at the Miami Open. She beat Sabine Lisicki in three sets to reach the semi-finals. Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals. Andy Murray also received a cake for his 500th win.

Sabeen Mahmud, who ran a cafe in Karachi, Pakistan, was shot and killed after hosting a discussion on a topic many want silenced. Mahmud was known for her free speech and promotion of humanism, love, and tolerance. She had previously received death threats for discussing the topic of Balochistan. Her cafe, T2F, was a place for those seeking secular wisdom and freedom of thought.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee, fled to Kashmir 70 years ago and is still considered a second-class citizen, unable to own property or vote in state elections.  He and 100,000 other West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) are hopeful for change after a Hindu nationalist party gained power in the Muslim-majority state.  The WPRs are denied rights due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance, and a pre-independence law that only grants citizenship to those born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir.  Despite living in poverty, they are hopeful that the new government will grant them state-subject rights.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Chelsea, who have made an offer of around £4 million. Chelsea would loan Muto to Vitesse Arnhem, but Muto wants to join a club where he will play regularly. Muto is a fast, strong, and intelligent player, according to his former coach. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto and admits that commercial interests play a part in the club's transfer policy.

Australia has dropped their policy of not selecting overseas players, which England should follow. Stuart Lancaster should be able to pick the best players, regardless of where they play. Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell are examples of top-class performers playing overseas. Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon have also improved since moving overseas. Jonny Wilkinson also improved when he moved to France. England should pick their best team for the World Cup, and not be restricted by the RFU or premier rugby.

Open Garden's Firechat app allows users to chat without internet or mobile signal by creating wireless mesh networks. Their new device, Greenstone, acts as a beacon to strengthen these networks. Firechat uses Apple's multipeer connectivity framework (MCF) and a similar Android feature to send messages via localized networks where phones act as nodes. Greenstone extends the range of these networks, and can hold up to 1,000 messages.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer, is trying to remove negativity from the word 'fat' by using it as a body-positive descriptor. She also calls herself 'short' and 'wife' as they are honest descriptions of herself. She notes that 'fat' does not have to be a synonym for 'ugly'. Size discrimination in the workplace has risen 66% in the past 30 years and the top 'magic wish' for girls 11 to 17 is to be thinner. Studies show that the more people are exposed to body diversity, the more they accept different body types. Lillian performs burlesque to expose her audiences to a 'fat' body in a positive way. She was initially nervous about her first performance but now feels great about her body. Her TED talk has received mostly positive feedback.

Theo Walcott has been pictured sitting on the bench with his Arsenal teammates. He and his teammates posed for an official portrait for Lanvin, the club's official tailor. Walcott has spent much of the season on the bench and has been named on the substitutes' bench for 17 of their 33 Premier League games.

A collection of props and puppets created by make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned off on May 29th at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on propstore.com. The collection from Baker's Cinovation Studio is worth an estimated $746,100 and includes 417 original items from more than 50 productions. Some of the items include the alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black, the Two Face mask from Batman Forever, the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas, and items from other films such as Gremlins 2, Batman & Robin, and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy, died in the French Alps after becoming separated from his mother while skiing. He entered dense woodland and fell over a 164ft drop. Carwyn was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster who was a competent skier and snowboarder. His family described him as an adorable, caring person who made life full of laughter. The family was on their last run of the day when Carwyn's sister lost her ski, and Carwyn went ahead. His mother stopped to help his sister, and Carwyn was not seen again. Police found his body by following his footprints in the snow.

Laura Scurr, 15, developed anorexia after becoming obsessed with her weight. She was hospitalized and put on a heart monitor after collapsing from starvation. Laura hid food and lied about eating, sometimes consuming only one piece of fruit a day. She felt pressure to be a size zero. After treatment, she is now in the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that aims to stay away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool unveiled their new home kit, designed by New Balance, who replaced Warrior as their suppliers in a £300 million deal. Players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, and Simon Mignolet modeled the kit at Anfield. Fans expressed their desire for Sterling to remain at the club, despite his recent rejection of a new contract and links to Arsenal. The players also discussed their upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa. The new kit features white branding and a new collar, with a tribute to the Hillsborough disaster.

A high-definition map of dark matter has been produced, covering 0.4% of the sky, with the goal to eventually map 12.5% over five years. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Victor M. Blanco telescope. Dark matter, which makes up 80% of the matter in the universe, is invisible but its effects can be seen by studying the distortion of light around distant galaxies. The map shows how the amount of dark matter corresponds to the formation rate of galaxies. The survey will be completed by 2018, mapping dark matter of an eighth of the sky.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay. Manager Louis van Gaal is familiar with Depay, having named him in his 2014 World Cup squad. Tottenham had a £15 million offer rejected last summer. Now, Manchester United and Paris Saint-Germain are interested in signing Depay. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season. PSV Eindhoven won the Dutch championship for the first time in seven seasons. Depay started at VV Moordrecht at age six, moved to PSV at 12, and made his first-team debut in 2011. He is known for his dribbling, shooting, and pace. Some believe he could be as good as Arjen Robben or even better than a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay was selected for the 2014 World Cup squad and scored two goals.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City's young side with a 3-1 victory, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke scoring late. Several players from both teams were highlighted for their performances, including Kjetil Haug, Pablo Maffeo, Tosin Adarabioyo, Cameron Humphreys-Grant, Jose Angelino Tasende, Kean Bryan, Aaron Nemane, Bersant Celina, Manu Garcia, Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, Brandon Barker, Bradley Collins, Fikayo Tomori, Ola Aina, Jake Clarke-Salter, Jay Dasilva, Ruben Sammut, Charlie Colkett, Charly Musonda, Isaiah Brown, and Kasey Palmer.

Marco Rubio believes people are born with a sexual preference, but that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and that states should regulate marriage. He would attend a same-sex wedding of someone he cared for, even though he believes marriage should be between one man and one woman. He also believes divorce is wrong, but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio is running for president and has received monetary commitments in excess of $51 million.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are cycling around the world with no set plans. They quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester and have been traveling for almost a year, covering 7,000 miles through 16 countries. They live on less than three euros each a day by camping, using hosting websites, and relying on free food when possible. They started in London and have traveled through Europe and into Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue into Asia and the Americas.

A Texas couple who got married in 2012 is suing James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing "poor n***** party" on photo booth pictures at their wedding. The couple was not aware of the racist message until months later when the bride's sister told them. Evans reportedly did not apologize and told the couple to sue him. The couple is suing for negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the allegations, claiming there is no evidence linking his company to the caption and that the couple showed no mental anguish. The couple's lawyer says they want an apology. Mediation is scheduled, and if no agreement is reached, the case will go to trial in July.

Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion and is unsure when he will return to play. George North has been advised not to play again this season after suffering four concussions. Brown had a headache after the France game and is being cautious to avoid a long break like Johnny Sexton or Geoff Parling. Brown was knocked out in the game against Italy in February. He pulled out of the Ireland game due to concussion symptoms. Brown says that learning about the symptoms of concussion helped him realize he was not ready to play.

Smartphone use may be to blame for a drop in the number of times couples are having sex each month. The frequency with which Britons are having sex has been in decline since the emergence of the internet. A typical heterosexual couple was now having sex three times a month, compared to four times a month in 2000 and five times a month in 1990. People are checking their emails all the time, and do not have the same sort of quiet empty time that there used to be. As we've become better connected technologically, our lives have become busier with the boundaries eroded between home, work and the outside world.

Tibetan mastiffs, which can weigh 80 kg, were once very popular in China, with some selling for up to £1.2 million. However, they are now unpopular due to an anti-corruption crackdown and bans on owning large dogs in some cities. As a result, they are being sent to slaughterhouses for meat and leather. Some are also being stolen and sold to slaughterhouses. The breed's quality has also deteriorated due to cross-breeding.

Every woman surveyed in Paris claimed to have been a victim of some kind of sexual harassment on the city's public transport. Half of them were assaulted before they were 18 years old. The poll led to calls for a campaign to stem sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains. Six out of ten women were afraid of being attacked on public transport compared to three out of ten men.

Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix where groups designed products to solve common problems. The top three prototypes are: 'Snooze', an alarm clock that silences phone notifications; 'Forget Me Lock', a device that indicates if a door is locked; and 'Nipper', a small mobile phone charger. People can vote for their favorite on Twitter by retweeting the corresponding tweet. The winning product will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

A police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under investigation for awarding over £500,000 of public funds to a charity, Victims First Northumbria, where she is a director. The charity's other director is the force's chief constable, Sue Sim. Critics have called this a conflict of interest and inappropriate. The Ministry of Justice is investigating whether conflict of interest rules were broken.

Three people were sentenced to prison and two are awaiting sentencing for assaulting a 53-year-old man. Corry Campbell, the ringleader, was sentenced to 20 years. Sandra Ng was sentenced to 23 months. Carl Halin received 20 years. David Harrison is awaiting sentencing. Jennifer Pratt is awaiting trial. The victim was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed. The assault occurred because Campbell believed the victim hurt his cat and stole money and weed.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay. Manager Louis van Gaal is familiar with Depay, having named him in his 2014 World Cup squad. Tottenham had a £15 million offer rejected last summer.  Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season. PSV won the Dutch championship for the first time in seven seasons. Depay started at VV Moordrecht at age six, moved to PSV at 12, and made his first-team debut in 2011. He is known for his dribbling, shooting, and left-wing play.  He was nominated for the World Cup's 'best young player' award.
